questions.prompt: Are LUGUBRIOUS people fun to have around?
Would winning a million dollars MITIGATE one's financial problems?
Is a PATENT mistake easy to spot?
Would a mother enjoy hearing her child make PLAINTIVE sounds?
Would a generous person readily ACCEDE to a request?
Would a stodgy person be DROLL?
Could a yawn be evidence of ENNUI?
Can a headache make one INDISPOSED?
Is a conviction the same as an INJUNCTION?
Could amusing stories REGALE a person?
Sally EVINCED her anger by slamming the door behind her.
The LUGUBRIOUS man laughed heartily at the story of our adventures.
The judge said that, since there were no MITIGATING circumstances, he would have to impose the full penalty prescribed by law.
The track coach said it was PATENTLY impossible for anyone to run so fast.
The critic said that the actors who had PERPETRATED these dismal performances should be banned from the theater.
The student PLAINTIVELY requested just one more day in which to finish the report.
The unruly prisoners became TRACTABLE when they were threatened with further punishment.
He ACCEDED to us all we could ask for.
The king placed the DIADEM on the young prince's head as a symbol of the transfer of power
The DROLL tolling of the bell told us the funeral was over.
Jack's ENNUI deepened as they continued to talk about things he wasn't interested in.
Jane was INDISPOSED to help someone who had been rude to her.
She ignored the dentist's INJUNCTION to brush her teeth after every meal.
Their mother REGALED them to clean up their rooms fast.
Students enjoyed the professor's occasional VAGARIES more than his formal presentation of the material.

EVINCE.deftext:
to exhibit, manifest, reveal 
To EVINCE is to show or demonstrate clearly by some outward sign. The word is applied to emotions, interests, and the like, not to physical characteristics. 
"He EVINCED no desire to go with us." 
"EVINCING his displeasure with a frown, the manager told Bill to come to his office." 
"The judge said he would have been more lenient if the criminals had EVINCED any regret."

LUGUBRIOUS.deftext:
mournful, dismal, melancholy, doleful 
LUGUBRIOUS means "expressing, or giving rise to, great sorrow." Usually the word is used in a half-humorous sense, about a person or thing that is gloomy in an excessive or exaggerated way. 
"The LUGUBRIOUS organ music seemed out of place in the modern office building." 
"The LUGUBRIOUS man could talk of nothing but funerals and graveyards." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is _merry_, which is opposite in meaning to LUGUBRIOUS. Perhaps people are misled by the humorous way.in which LUGUBRIOUS is often used.

MITIGATE.deftext:
to soften, moderate, alleviate, relieve 
To MITIGATE something is to make it less severe or painful, to moderate its force or intensity. 
"The judge refused to MITIGATE Stanley's punishment, even though he promised never to steal again." 
"The warm fire and pleasant conversation somewhat MITIGATED the inconvenience of being snowbound." 
"MITIGATING circumstances" are those that might tend to lessen the severity of an offense. 
"The man admitted he had stolen the car, but argued that there were MITIGATING circumstances: his wife was about to have a baby, and they had no other way of getting to the hospital." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is "argue over," possibly due to confusion with _litigate_, which means "to engage in legal proceedings." 
Other forms of the word: MITIGATION, n. MITIGATIVE, adj.

PATENTLY.deftext:
obviously, clearly, plainly 
The adjective PATENT means "open to view," _obvious_, _evident_. 
"Her displeasure with the worker was PATENT: she stormed back and forth, shaking her head and muttering threats." 
The adverbial form of the word, PATENTLY, is perhaps seen more frequently. It means _obviously_, _clearly_. 
"The expert said the painting was PATENTLY a fake, done by a crude amateur." 
"His claim to be the world's greatest writer was PATENTLY ridiculous." 
Other forms of the word: PATENT, adj.

PERPETRATE.deftext:
to commit, perform, carry out 
To PERPETRATE means to _commit_. The word is usually applied to crimes, but may also refer to actions which, though not criminal, are offensive or deplorable. 
"The butler was accused of PERPETRATING the murder." 
"The bank robberies were PERPETRATED by a gang of master criminals." 
"The angry teacher said that whoever had PERPETRATED the practical joke would be punished." 
Other forms of the word: PERPETRATION, n. PERPETRATOR, n.

PLAINTIVE.deftext:
mournful, melancholy, sorrowful, doleful 
PLAINTIVE is related to the word _complaint_. Both come originally from a Latin word meaning "to beat one's breast," to _lament_. PLAINTIVE means _sorrowful_, _melancholy_. It is usually used about sounds that are mournful or pitiful. 
"In a PLAINTIVE voice the child said he couldn't find his mother." 
"The PLAINTIVE melody of the Chopin nocturne made me feel sad and reflective." 
"The hungry man PLAINTIVELY begged for food." 
_Questioning_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, possibly because to _complain_ about something is in a sense to _question_ it.

TRACTABLE.deftext:
obedient, governable, docile 
TRACTABLE means "able to be easily controlled or handled." It is used about persons and animals. 
"The child became quite TRACTABLE when we told her she couldn't watch TV if she didn't obey us." 
"Beth was afraid of horses, so we let her ride the TRACTABLE old mare before trying any of the more spirited horses." 
When used about things, TRACTABLE can mean "easy to work with," _malleable_. 
"The sculptor found this type of clay to be quite TRACTABLE and used it in many of his works." 
The opposite of TRACTABLE, INTRACTABLE, is frequently used. 
"The INTRACTABLE child simply refused to eat his spinach." 
Other forms of the word: INTRACTABLE, adj. TRACTABILITY, n.

ACCEDE.deftext:
to agree, assent, consent 
The _cede_ part of ACCEDE comes from a Latin word meaning to _yield_, also found in _concede_ and _cede_. See _ad-_ under Prefixes. To ACCEDE to something is to yield to it, to give one's assent to it, often after persuasion. It is followed by _to_. 
"If you do not ACCEDE to our demands we will go on strike." 
"The professor ACCEDED to Jim's request for an extra day to complete his paper." 
"The treasurer was not prepared to ACCEDE to any changes in the budget." 
_Give_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps because of the word _cede_.

DIADEM.deftext:
a crown, ornamental headband 
A DIADEM was originally a cloth headband worn by Eastern monarchs as a sign of their royal power and dignity. This custom was taken over by Alexander the Great when he conquered their countries. DIADEM then came to be used for any kind of crown used as an emblem of royalty. In an extended sense, DIADEM can be used to refer to the royalty itself. 
"The emperor wore his DIADEM only on ceremonial occasions." 
"Upon the death of the king, several powerful dukes contended for the DIADEM and scepter of royal power."

DROLL.deftext:
comical, laughable, amusing 
DROLL comes from a French noun meaning "jolly little fellow," _buffoon_, and the word is still used in this way. But it is most frequently used as an adjective and means "amusing in a sly, odd, or whimsical way." The word suggests the soft-spoken humor of a Yankee storyteller rather than the broad slapstick of a clown. 
"Mr. Peters told us a DROLL story about being mistaken for a famous movie star." 
"The DROLL bartender had a funny story on every subject." 
"We were all amused by the chimpanzee's DROLL actions." 
Many people think DROLL means _serious_, which has virtually the opposite meaning. A DROLL person may have a serious expression while telling a funny story, and this may be a cause of the confusion. 
Other forms of the word: DROLLERY, n.

ENNUI.deftext:
boredom, tedium 
Note the pronunciation. ENNUI is from the French, and keeps its French pronunciation. ENNUI is a feeling of dissatisfaction and weariness that stems from a lack of interest in one's surroundings and activities. People who feel ENNUI lack the energy or the desire to do the kinds of things they might previously have enjoyed. 
"Susan tried to relieve her ENNUI by going skiing in the Rockies, but when she came back she was just as bored as ever." 
"The sameness of his life provoked a strong sense of ENNUI in Mr. Simpson. He just didn't feel like doing the same old job, day in and day out." 
"John had such a strong feeling of ENNUI that all he did was lie around the house all day."

INDISPOSED.deftext:
mildly ill; unwilling 
One meaning of the verb _dispose_ is "to be willing or receptive." 
"I am DISPOSED to believe you." 
To be INDISPOSED is to be unwilling or disinclined. See _in-2_ under Prefixes. 
"Bill was tired and grumpy and generally INDISPOSED to listen to Ralph's excuses." 
INDISPOSED is usually seen with a very different meaning: _mildly ill_. The image is of a person who is not feeling well and is therefore not disposed to do something. 
"When Ted called, Marge's roommate said she was INDISPOSED and couldn't come to the phone." 
"The performance had to be canceled because the star was INDISPOSED." 
Other forms of the word: INDISPOSITION, n.

INJUNCTION.deftext:
an order, command, directive 
An INJUNCTION is a command to do or not do something. 
"With a last INJUNCTION to eat well and wear clean socks, the anxious mother sent her son off to summer camp." 
"He conscientiously obeyed his doctor's INJUNCTION not to eat tomatoes." 
INJUNCTION is a frequently used term in law, where it refers to a court order that must be obeyed on penalty of being held in contempt of court. 
"The court issued an INJUNCTION against the illegal strike." 
"The reporter disobeyed the court's INJUNCTION to hand over his notes."

REGALE.deftext:
to delight, entertain, gratify 
REGALE is related to the word _regal_. It means "to entertain or give pleasure to." The word suggests the kind of lavish or sumptuous entertainment a king would provide. 
"Mary REGALED her guests with fine wines and delicious cheeses." 
"The speaker REGALED the audience with his tales of life on the high seas." 
"Jim liked to REGALE himself with memories of the athletic triumphs of his college days."

VAGARY.deftext:
a whim, caprice, flight of fancy 
A VAGARY is a fanciful, extravagant idea or notion. 
"No one was quite sure if the learned man's occasional strange ideas were harmless VAGARIES or brilliant insights." 
In a slightly different sense, a VAGARY is an unpredictable or erratic action. 
"The VAGARIES of New England weather make it a chancy thing to plan outdoor activities." 
"Experts tried in vain to explain the VAGARIES of the stock market."

questions.prompt: Are lazy people known for their ALACRITY?
Does a rowdy COMPORT himself with dignity?
Are you a DENIZEN of the universe?
Can heat cause things to DESICCATE?
Can a trap door be an EGRESS?
Are IMPECUNIOUS people likely to spend a great deal of money?
Would a person generally be pleased by MALEDICTIONS?
Would a person take UMBRAGE at being cursed at?
Would a person who is ABSCONDING be in a hurry?
Can a love story be LACHRYMOSE?
The cider had an unpleasant ACETOUS taste that told us it had gone bad.
Her ALACRITY in accepting the job startled the interviewer.
Mary COMPORTED herself better than anyone else in the contest.
His CURSORY attempts to keep us informed showed that he really didn't care what we knew.
The exterminator said he would get rid of the termites, carpenter ants, and any other unwanted DENIZENS of the house.
The piece of fruit was old and DESICCATED and did not look very appetizing.
The fire blocked their only means of EGRESS from the building.
The IMPECUNIOUS man finally went bankrupt.
The speaker's MALADROIT witticisms did little to put the audience at ease.
The priest uttered a brief MALEDICTION for us before we set off on the dangerous journey.
We offered the MENDICANT what food and money we could spare.
The SALUTARY woman said she had never felt better in her life.
Mrs. Fields took UMBRAGE at the teacher's comment that her son watched too much television.
Three teenagers ABSCONDED the liquor store of a thousand dollars.
The LACHRYMOSE girl found a dozen things to weep about in the newspaper every morning.

ACETOUS.deftext:
vinegary, sour tasting 
ACETOUS comes from the Latin word for _vinegar_. It means "pertaining to or producing vinegar." It is sometimes used in an extended sense to mean generally _sour_ or _sour tasting_. 
"The chemical formula produces an ACETOUS solution that is very sour to the taste." 
"The sarcastic man made some ACETOUS comments about the way the government was being run."

ALACRITY.deftext:
eagerness, readiness, willingness 
ALACRITY is promptness, eagerness, lively readiness. The word is used with regard to a person who is eager or quite willing to do something, and who will respond quickly and cheerfully when asked. 
"When Charles asked her to the party, she accepted with ALACRITY." 
"The ALACRITY with which George went on overtime surprised his boss; he hadn't thought George needed the money." 
"When the call came, the firemen responded with ALACRITY: they were dressed and in their engines in thirty seconds."

COMPORT.deftext:
to behave, conduct; to agree, correspond 
COMPORT means to _behave_. It is used reflexively—that is, with a word such as _himself_, _herself_, or _themselves_. 
"James COMPORTED himself with great dignity at his father's funeral." 
"At the opera Ann COMPORTED herself in such a way that we knew she went there all the time." 
In a different sense, COMPORT can mean to _agree_ or _correspond_. In this sense the word is followed by _with_. 
"The statements in this book do not COMPORT with our current understanding of the facts." 
Other forms of the word: COMPORTMENT, n.

CURSORY.deftext:
superficial, hasty 
CURSORY comes from a Latin word meaning to _run_, also the source of _current_ and _course_. CURSORY means "done hastily and without thoroughness," _superficial_. The word usually suggests casualness and lack of attention to detail. 
"With a single CURSORY glance at the painting the expert said it was obviously a fake." 
"Jim had time for only a CURSORY reading of the report before the meeting." 
"The president made a CURSORY reference to the problem, but didn't go into any detail about how he would solve it." 
Many people pick _swift_ as the word closest in meaning to CURSORY on the Pretest. CURSORY certainly suggests swiftness, but the emphasis in the word is on the lack of care and thoroughness brought about by one's speed of doing something.

DENIZEN.deftext:
an inhabitant, resident 
A DENIZEN is an inhabitant of a region or a country, particularly one who belongs there by birth or naturalization. 
"The stranger's wild appearance shocked the staid DENIZENS of the small town." 
"At the aquarium we saw sharks, squid, and other DENIZENS of the ocean." 
"The woodsman was familiar with all the DENIZENS of the forest."

DESICCATE.deftext:
to dry up, dry thoroughly 
To DESICCATE is to dry thoroughly, to remove all the moisture from. 
"The intense dry heat DESICCATED all the logs we had cut." 
It can also mean to _become dry_. 
"All the plants DESICCATED during the drought." 
In a specific sense, DESICCATE can mean "to preserve (a food) by removing the moisture." In an extension of its basic meaning, DESICCATE also means "to make dry or dull, to drain of interest and vitality." 
"The critic called the play stale and DESICCATED, devoid of intellectual or human interest." 
"The professor claimed that censorship DESICCATED art by removing all that was fresh and vital in it." 
Other forms of the word: DESICCATION, n. DESICCATIVE, adj.

EGRESS.deftext:
exit, departure 
EGRESS comes from a Latin word meaning to _go out_. See _e-_ under Prefixes. The _gress_ root, meaning _go_, is also found in such words as _progress_ and _regress_. An EGRESS is the act of leaving a place. 
"The students' EGRESS from the classroom at the end of the day was rapid and noisy." 
An EGRESS is also the place by means of which one departs, an exit. 
"The only EGRESS from the room was a skylight far above his head."

IMPECUNIOUS.deftext:
penniless, indigent, needy 
_Pecunia_ is the Latin word for _money_. It is found in the English words _pecuniary_, "having to do with money," and IMPECUNIOUS. See _in-2_ under Prefixes and _-ous_ under Suffixes. The basic meaning of IMPECUNIOUS is "not having money." IMPECUNIOUS generally implies that this is a more or less continuous state, and sometimes suggests that it is the person's own fault, because of overspending. 
"The IMPECUNIOUS young man was constantly borrowing money from his friends." 
"Her IMPECUNIOUS father was forever having difficulty making the mortgage payments on the house."

MALADROIT.deftext:
awkward, clumsy; tactless, inept 
The French and Latin prefix _mal-_ means _bad_ or _badly_. Someone who is MALADROIT is "badly adroit," is not at all skillful or dexterous. The word can be used about physical clumsiness, but it is more frequently applied to a lack of tact or good judgment in social situations. 
"The president's MALADROIT remarks managed to offend just about everyone at the meeting." 
"Her MALADROIT attempt to make excuses for herself only got her into deeper trouble." 
"Betty detested family gatherings; try as she would, she always seemed to say something MALADROIT and offend someone."

MALEDICTION.deftext:
a curse, slander 
The _dic_ part of MALEDICTION comes from a Latin word meaning _speak_; it is also found in words like _diction_, _dictation_, _predict_, and _contradict_. The _mal_ part of the word means _bad_; see _maladroit_ in this chapter. A MALEDICTION is bad speech directed at someone, a curse or slander. It is the opposite of _benediction_, which is a _blessing_. 
"The witch uttered a grim MALEDICTION against her torturers." 
"Despite the MALEDICTIONS of his opponents the governor was reelected."

MENDICANT.deftext:
a beggar 
A MENDICANT is a person who lives by begging. 
"The MENDICANT went from house to house, begging for alms." 
MENDICANT is also an adjective meaning "practicing begging." 
"The MENDICANT friars depended on the charity of the townspeople for food and shelter." 
MENDICANT orders are religious orders whose members are not allowed to own property, and who originally had to live by receiving alms.

SALUTARY.deftext:
wholesome, healthful, salubrious, remedial 
SALUTARY comes from the Latin word for _health_. Its basic meaning is "promoting health." 
"This ointment's effect is SALUTARY; it will be quite an effective medicine." 
In an extended sense, SALUTARY means "producing a beneficial effect." In this sense, it is often used about things that may be temporarily unpleasant, but ultimately will be helpful. 
"The doctor said that a salt-free diet would prove to be SALUTARY in the long run." 
"This SALUTARY criticism helped the pianist overcome many of her problems." 
"The SALUTARY debate forced both sides to think more deeply about the issue."

UMBRAGE.deftext:
offense, resentment, annoyance 
UMBRAGE is usually used in the phrases "to give UMBRAGE" or "to take UMBRAGE." To take UMBRAGE is to take offense, often because one's pride is hurt. 
"John took UMBRAGE at the coach's suggestion that he wasn't trying hard." 
"I'm afraid I gave UMBRAGE to Mr. Donnelly with my remarks about his children." 
"Jones said he didn't feel any UMBRAGE about being passed over for the promotion, because he didn't think he was qualified."

ABSCOND.deftext:
to depart hurriedly and secretly, flee, escape 
To ABSCOND is to leave in a sudden and secret manner, generally to avoid the consequences of a crime. 
"The embezzler ABSCONDED with millions of dollars of the bank's money." 
"When the Internal Revenue Service began investigating his tax returns, Bill decided to ABSCOND from the country." 
"The mobster chose to ABSCOND rather than stand trial for murder." 
_Rob_ is the most common wrong answer, chosen by people who know that ABSCOND has something to do with crime. Robbers might ABSCOND after committing their crime, but ABSCOND means to _flee_, not to _rob_.

LACHRYMOSE.deftext:
tearful, weepy; melancholy, mournful 
LACHRYMOSE comes from the Latin word for _tear_ and means "given to tears or weeping." The word usually has a somewhat negative sense, suggesting that the weepiness is excessive. 
"When he was drunk he became quite LACHRYMOSE, weeping over the sins of his past and the state of the world." 
LACHRYMOSE also means "causing tears," _melancholy_. 
"After his defeat the politician made a LACHRYMOSE speech, full of self-pity and resentment." 
"Their farewell at the airport was long and LACHRYMOSE. They didn't know if they'd ever see each other again."

questions.prompt: Would a PUERILE plan excite admiration?
Is a brief examination likely to lead to a TRENCHANT analysis?
Would a person dislike being BUFFETED?
Would a CRAVEN be brave during a battle?
Is a DIDACTIC person usually ignorant?
Are witnesses at a trial supposed to PREVARICATE?
Is a person getting better during the INCIPIENT stages of a disease?
Is general a RAREFIED rank in the army?
Would a frightened person possess SANGFROID?
Would a beggar be in need of SUCCOR?
Could a movie critic possess ACERBITY?
Would shepherds live in a BUCOLIC area?
Her PUERILE chatter convinced us she didn't have the maturity required for the job.
All the actors felt the sting of the critic's TRENCHANT comments.
She had received so many BUFFETS at the hands of Fate that finally she just gave up.
The CRAVEN general saved his own skin while endangering all his troops.
There is so much DETRITUS in the basement that we'll never get it all cleaned out.
Her DIDACTIC speech told us more than we wanted to know about the benefits of virtuous living.
The fireman PREVARICATED us from entering the burning building.
Grandma's INCIPIENT deafness caused her to occasionally miss snatches of the conversation.
The announcer's PITHY comments heightened our enjoyment of the football game.
Buffalo are almost completely RAREFIED in that part of the country.
Phipps could tell the most outrageous lies with complete SANGFROID, even when speaking to very important people.
The relief agencies could provide little SUCCOR for the thousands of unemployed.
The ACERBITY of the teacher's comments showed she didn't think much of Steve's paper.
Albert feared any BUCOLIC intrusion into his already busy life.
These CALUMNIES cannot be allowed to go unchallenged, or people will start believing them.

PUERILE.deftext:
childish, juvenile, foolish 
PUERILE comes from the Latin word for boy, _puer_. Someone who is PUERILE is boyish, childish. It is an uncomplimentary term that suggests immaturity, even foolishness. 
"'Stop being so PUERILE—it's time to grow up', she would say whenever her husband threw a tantrum." 
"You may be twenty-one-years old, but your PUERILE behavior makes you seem about ten." 
Other forms of the word: PUERILITY, n.

TRENCHANT.deftext:
incisive, keen, effective 
TRENCHANT was originally applied to objects and meant _sharp_, _keen_, as a "TRENCHANT blade." That meaning is now obsolete and the word is only used figuratively to describe speech, thought, or manner that penetrates or cuts to the heart of an issue. 
"The speaker's comments on civil rights were TRENCHANT: we saw the issue more clearly than ever before." 
"The judge's TRENCHANT analysis of the case aided the jury in its debate." 
"The politician's grave manner made his utterances seem TRENCHANT even when they were nonsensical." 
Other forms of the word: TRENCHANCY, n.

BUFFET.deftext:
to strike, hit, batter, beat, thrash 
To BUFFET is to hit repeatedly as if with an open hand. The word can be used about actual physical beating, or it can be used figuratively. 
"High waves BUFFETED the sides of the ship." 
"He had been constantly BUFFETED by the misfortunes of life." 
BUFFET is also a noun. 
"The house withstood the BUFFETS of the tree branches during the hurricane." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is _protect_, probably due to a confusion of BUFFET and _buffer_, which is something that protects by reducing the shock of impact or by shielding from undesirable pressures.

CRAVEN.deftext:
cowardly, pusillanimous 
CRAVEN is both a noun and an adjective. A CRAVEN is an abject coward, someone who is contemptibly fearful in the face of danger. 
"The CRAVEN turned and ran as soon as he saw the enemy soldiers in the distance." 
As an adjective CRAVEN is used about people and activities that demonstrate this cowardice. 
"The CRAVEN scoundrel challenged me to a duel, then fled the city when I accepted his challenge." 
"Your CRAVEN refusal to stand up for your principles sickens me."

DETRITUS.deftext:
debris 
DETRITUS is the loose material that forms from the abrasion or erosion of rocks. In an extended sense, DETRITUS is used about fragmented material of any sort, _debris_. 
"After the avalanche, all that remained of the cliff was DETRITUS." 
"The flood victims searched among the DETRITUS of their homes for prized possessions." 
DETRITUS can also be used figuratively. 
"The woman tried in vain to dredge the visitor's name from the DETRITUS of her memory."

DIDACTIC.deftext:
instructive, pedantic 
DIDACTIC means "intended to teach," often some moral lesson. It is frequently used in a derogatory sense about someone or something that tries to teach too much or too often. 
"DIDACTIC Aunt Betty never missed a chance to instruct: even a social call was turned into a lecture." 
"The professor was so DIDACTIC that he would quiz a student if he met him in the hall." 
"The history text is accurate, but so dry and DIDACTIC that it's impossible to read."

PREVARICATE.deftext:
to lie, equivocate 
PREVARICATE comes from a Latin word meaning "to walk crookedly." In English, to PREVARICATE is to stray from the path of the truth. It is a formal and high-sounding synonym of _lie_. It is also used to suggest a weaker kind of "avoiding the truth." 
"The student attempted to PREVARICATE, and said he hadn't really meant to cheat, but the book just happened to be open on his lap." 
"Ed's boss accused him of PREVARICATING when he said that the report must have been lost in the mail." 
Other forms of the word: PREVARICATION, n. PREVARICATOR, n.

INCIPIENT.deftext:
beginning, commencing, initial 
INCIPIENT means "at an early stage," _beginning_. It comes from a Latin verb meaning "to take in hand," and thus to _start_. The _cip_ root, meaning to _take_, is also found in the word _recipient_. 
"The INCIPIENT revolt was crushed before it had a chance to spread." 
"The INCIPIENT stage of the illness is characterized by nausea and a low fever." 
"The president thought it was an INCIPIENT problem and should be taken care of before it became serious." 
Other forms of the word: INCIPIENCE, n. INCIPIENCY, n.

PITHY.deftext:
terse, concise, cogent 
A PITHY statement is one that is both brief and full of substance, so that it is particularly effective. 
"His argument was intelligent and PITHY; the opposition had no time to think of a rebuttal." 
"The father and daughter corresponded with notes that were short but PITHY; all the important information was transmitted." 
"Angela preferred the PITHY news reports on television to the wordiness of the newspaper." 
_Sarcastic_ is chosen more often than the correct answer, _concise_. PITHY remarks are short and forceful and often witty; they may be sarcastic, but they do not have to be.

RAREFIED.deftext:
exalted, elevated, esoteric 
The basic meaning of the verb to RAREFY is to _make rare_. From this it came to mean "to make more spiritual." RAREFIED is the adjective from RAREFY. It can mean "of interest to a small select group," _esoteric_. 
"The art of glass-blowing has become so RAREFIED that only a few craftsmen now practice it." 
Or it can mean _exalted_, _lofty_, usually in a figurative sense. 
"The young ballplayer aspired to the RAREFIED heights of the Hall of Fame." 
"We were completely lost in this RAREFIED realm of pure mathematics." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _unknown_, probably a guess based on the _rare_ in RAREFIED. Other forms of the word: RAREFY, v.

SANGFROID.deftext:
composure, equanimity, self-possession, imperturbability 
Note the pronunciation. SANGFROID is from the French, and keeps its French pronunciation. SANGFROID literally means "cold blood" in French. In English SANGFROID is used for the quality of great coolness and self-possession, especially under trying circumstances. 
"With incredible SANGFROID he walked right up to the criminal and took the gun away from him." 
"You have to admire her SANGFROID. Millions of people were watching her performance, and it didn't seem to bother her at all." 
"Bill is somewhat lacking in SANGFROID. He gets very nervous when there is any pressure put on him." 
_Arrogance_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer. Arrogance is a characteristic that one might associate with SANGFROID, but the two words are not synonymous.

SUCCOR.deftext:
aid, assistance, relief 
SUCCOR means _help_, especially help given to someone in distress. 
"The Coast Guard is always there to give SUCCOR to ships in distress." 
"In times of trouble, the family found SUCCOR in their faith." 
SUCCOR is also the person or thing that gives help. 
"The Aid to Families with Dependent Children program is a great SUCCOR to poor people." 
SUCCOR is also used as a verb. 
"All attempts to SUCCOR the poor man and his family proved fruitless."

ACERBITY.deftext:
sourness, acidity of taste or manner 
ACERBITY comes from the Latin word for _sharp_. Its basic meaning in English is "sour or acid to the taste": "The cranberry's ACERBITY is such that you can't eat it without sugar." It is used more often in its extended sense of sourness of disposition, sharpness of manner. 
"The woman's ACERBITY made her a harsh mistress; nothing was ever done right, or quickly enough." 
"Barbara's quick mind and ACERBITY of manner made her a formidable debating opponent." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _quickness_, perhaps due to a confusion with the word _alacrity_. See _alacrity_ in Chapter 2. 
Other forms of the word: ACERB, adj. ACERBIC, adj.

BUCOLIC.deftext:
pastoral, rustic 
BUCOLIC means "pertaining to shepherds," _pastoral_. In a broader sense, it can refer to the life of the countryside generally. The word usually emphasizes the peacefulness and simplicity of rustic life. 
"Victoria felt sure she would be happy in this BUCOLIC setting of meadows and farms." 
"The BUCOLIC atmosphere was destroyed when the bulldozers appeared and started tearing up the fields." 
The wrong answer _poisonous_ attracts many people, probably due to confusion with the adjective _bubonic_. The _bubonic_ plague is a contagious, usually fatal disease transmitted by infected rats.

CALUMNY.deftext:
slander, detraction, defamation 
CALUMNY is the malicious telling of an untruth in order to hurt someone. 
"The candidate said that the rumors about her past were CALUMNY; she had never been to prison." 
"Famous people cannot escape CALUMNY; someone is always out to destroy their reputations." 
CALUMNY is also used about the false statement itself. 
"The movie star said she would sue the reporter over his outrageous CALUMNIES." 
"Paul said it was a CALUMNY even to suggest he might have cheated on the test." 
Other forms of the word: CALUMNIATE, v. CALUMNIOUS, adj.

questions.prompt: Is an argumentative person likely to CAVIL?
Would people be persuaded by a COGENT argument?
Can you walk on the FIRMAMENT?
Would a confident person be likely to act NONPLUSSED?
Is a lackluster person likely to be PREPOSSESSING?
Is RAPACITY a good trait to have?
Could one use curses in REVILING someone?
Would a SUPERCILIOUS person be likely to think of others as childish?
Is TORPOR a characteristic of lazy people?
Is TUMID flesh pleasant to look at?
Would nastiness be a characteristic of an UNCTUOUS person?
Should one be gullible when it comes to CANARDS?
Their mother CAVILED them for not doing their homework.
It is COGENT that we will have to do something about our old car pretty soon.
The explosion seemed to make the FIRMAMENT glow from one end to the other.
Those early years were fondly recalled as a HALCYON period in the organization's history.
Jim is NONPLUSSED at hockey; he is by far the best player on the team.
You didn't have to be so PREPOSSESSING, but we appreciated the thought.
Your arguments are RAPACIOUS; they make no sense at all.
The speaker REVILED the people who are unwilling to get involved in community affairs.
The playwright thought that this scene would be quite dramatic, but the audience found it RISIBLE.
Tom looked SUPERCILIOUS wearing that lampshade at the party.
The young radicals decried the intellectual TORPOR of the university.
It was difficult to breathe the hot, TUMID air.
The butler's UNCTUOUS manner completely hid his true feelings and opinions.
She ABJURED us to hurry, because time was running out.
No one believed the CANARD about the con man selling the Brooklyn Bridge to a rich tourist.

CAVIL.deftext:
to quibble, carp 
To CAVIL is to raise petty or trivial objections to something. It is usually used with _at_, _about_, or _with_. 
"A small group delayed the passage of the treaty for some time by CAVILING about its language." 
"I wish you wouldn't CAVIL at my grammar; you understand what I mean." 
"Critics' reviews often skim over the whole performance to CAVIL with minor details." 
CAVIL is also a noun, meaning a _trivial objection_. 
"Despite the CAVILS of petty critics, audiences seem to love the play."

COGENT.deftext:
convincing, forceful, compelling 
COGENT comes from a Latin word meaning to _force together_. See _co-_ under Prefixes. COGENT is usually applied to arguments, reasons, or the like, and means _forceful_, _convincing_. 
"Pete advanced several COGENT arguments about why he deserved a raise." 
"The principal made some COGENT remarks about the need for greater discipline in the school." 
"The mayor COGENTLY pointed out that taxes would have to be raised in order to pay for a new high school." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is _obvious_, probably due to a confusion of COGENT with _blatant_. 
Other forms of the word: COGENCY, n.

FIRMAMENT.deftext:
the heavens, sky, celestial sphere 
The word FIRMAMENT is difficult because the _firm_ part of the word makes people think it means _earth_, an opposite of its correct meaning, _sky_ or _heavens_. FIRMAMENT in fact is related to the word _firm_; it means _sky_ because of the ancient belief that the outermost portion of the heavens was actually solid, an arch or vault into which the stars were fixed. FIRMAMENT in modern usage is a poetic or literary word. 
"Every star in the FIRMAMENT seemed to blaze with an unnatural light." 
"Kate gazed up at the FIRMAMENT and wondered if one day she would travel to the stars."

HALCYON.deftext:
tranquil, calm, peaceful 
The HALCYON was a mythical bird that nested on the sea at the time of the winter solstice, and was supposed to have the power to calm the wind and the waves during that time. As an adjective, HALCYON refers to this magical calmness and tranquility. "HALCYON days" are literally the days of fine weather around the winter solstice; in extended use the phrase is applied to any tranquil time. 
"The man reflected that life was simpler and people were happier in the HALCYON days of his youth." 
"Summer vacations were a HALCYON time when we spent endless days relaxing on the beach." 
"The commencement speaker said that these HALCYON college days would stay in our memories all our lives."

NONPLUSSED.deftext:
perplexed, puzzled, baffled 
NONPLUSSED is also spelled NONPLUSED. 
The verb to NONPLUS comes from the Latin words _non plus_, meaning "no more." It suggests a state in which no more can be said or done because of profound puzzlement or perplexity. 
"The mayor's decision not to seek reelection NONPLUSSED his supporters. They couldn't understand why he wanted to leave the job." 
The word is usually seen in its adjective form, NONPLUSSED. 
"I was NONPLUSSED at the man's insults. Why would he say such things?" 
"The NONPLUSSED audience stared in disbelief as the conductor threw down his baton and walked offstage." 
The word is also occasionally used as a noun, in the expression _at_ or _to a_ NONPLUS. 
"We were reduced to a NONPLUS when the lamp suddenly started moving across the room." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _certain_, an opposite of NONPLUSSED. 
Other forms of the word: NONPLUS, n., v.

PREPOSSESSING.deftext:
attractive, pleasing 
To be PREPOSSESSING is to create a favorable impression. The word often suggests an obvious attractiveness that has an immediate, pleasant effect. See _pre-_ under Prefixes. 
"The friendly, PREPOSSESSING young man always did well in job interviews." 
"Her PREPOSSESSING appearance disposed people to think well of her as soon as they met her." 
"The album's PREPOSSESSING cover certainly helped its sales." 
_Kindly_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer. It is probably chosen by people who know that PREPOSSESSING is a positive word, hut don't have a clear idea of its meaning. 
Other forms of the word: PREPOSSESS, v.

RAPACIOUS.deftext:
greedy, grasping, plundering 
RAPACIOUS and _rape_ both come from a Latin word meaning to _seize_. RAPACIOUS means "seizing or grasping like a bird of prey" and usually suggests extreme greed. 
"The RAPACIOUS pirates seized everything on the defenseless ship." 
"The RAPACIOUS loanshark was unrelenting in the collection of his debts; he brought many people to financial ruin." 
The noun form of RAPACIOUS is RAPACITY. 
"The consumer advocate condemned the RAPACITY of businesses that cared only about making high profits without considering the cost to society." 
Other forms of the word: RAPACITY, n.

REVILE.deftext:
to abuse, rail against, denounce, malign 
To REVILE is to denounce or abuse, often at length. The _vile_ part of the word is from the same Latin word as the English words _vile_ and _vilify_. 
"The prisoner REVILED his captors as evil, soulless persecutors." 
"In his hook the author REVILES an economic system that can produce such human misery." 
"You shouldn't REVILE us for criticizing you; you should praise us for having the courage to say what we think." 
_Hate_ is by far the most commonly chosen wrong answer. This is an understandable confusion, since one will usually hate what one REVILES. But to REVILE something is to express one's hatred for it in abusive language.

RISIBLE.deftext:
funny, laughable, ludicrous 
RISIBLE comes from the Latin word meaning to _laugh_, also the source of _derision_ and _ridiculous_. See _-able_ under Suffixes. RISIBLE means "able to excite laughter," _laughable_. 
"The comedian's RISIBLE stories kept the audience laughing all night." 
"The sight of all those clowns trying to fit into the little car was quite RISIBLE." 
"The boy thought his insults were RISIBLE, hut no one else even smiled at them." 
Other forms of the word: RISIBILITY, n.

SUPERCILIOUS.deftext:
haughty, disdainful, arrogant 
SUPERCILIOUS means "having a haughty, superior manner." It comes from the Latin word for _eyebrow_; the image is of a person raising an eyebrow in disdain. 
"Her SUPERCILIOUS attitude infuriates us; why does she think she is so much better than the rest of us?" 
"With a SUPERCILIOUS sneer he said the miners' lives were too unimportant for him to worry about." 
"The SUPERCILIOUS boss does nothing but make cutting remarks about how stupid his workers are." 
_Ridiculous_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, probably because SUPERCILIOUS sounds like _super silly_.

TORPOR.deftext:
sluggishness, lethargy, lassitude 
TORPOR is mental or physical inactivity, like that of an animal in hibernation. In a slightly extended sense, the word can also be used as a synonym of _apathy_ or _lethargy_. 
"The drug caused a strange TORPOR to fall over the crew; they didn't have enough energy to lift their oars." 
"Nothing could rouse him from his TORPOR; he just wanted to lie in bed all day and sleep." 
TORPID is the adjective related to TORPOR. It means _lethargic_, _sluggish_. 
"Used to the hectic big city life, he can't adjust to the TORPID pace of village life." 
_Heat_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, probably because hot weather can be a cause of TORPOR. 
Other forms of the word: TORPID, adj.

TUMID.deftext:
swollen, distended, bloated 
TUMID is related to the word _tumor_; both come from a Latin word meaning to _swell_. TUMID means _swollen_, usually in an unhealthy way; it is usually used about parts of the body. 
"His foot became TUMID because of the infection." 
In an extended sense TUMID is often applied to language and means _overblown_, _bombastic_. 
"The old-fashioned politician's TUMID style made his speeches very dull to listen to." 
_Diseased_, the most commonly chosen wrong answer, is probably selected by people who make the connection of TUMID with _tumor_, but aren't sure of the exact meaning of TUMID.

UNCTUOUS.deftext:
oily, slippery, greasy 
UNCTUOUS comes from the Latin word for _ointment_; it is related to the word _unguent_, which is an ointment or salve. The basic meaning of UNCTUOUS is _oily_ or _greasy_, like an ointment. It is most often used in an extended sense about people with an oily manner, particularly when they are hypocritically ingratiating. 
"The woman was completely taken in by the salesman's UNCTUOUS flattery." 
"The new minister's UNCTUOUS air of spirituality strikes many members of the congregation as completely phony." 
_Proud_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps due to confusion with the equally unpleasant word _pompous_.

ABJURE.deftext:
to renounce, recant, forswear, retract 
The _jure_ part of ABJURE comes from a Latin word meaning to _swear_. This word is also the source of the word _jury_, which is a group of people sworn to give a verdict in a legal case. See _ab-_ under Prefixes. To ABJURE something is to "swear away" from it, to renounce it solemnly or publicly. 
"The knight solemnly ABJURED his oath of allegiance to the former king and swore to follow King Henry instead." 
"The new members have to ABJURE violence as a means of changing society." 
"In a public ceremony the convert to the religion ABJURED his former beliefs."

CANARD.deftext:
a false story, groundless report 
CANARD is the French word for _duck_. It comes into English by way of a French phrase that means "to half-sell a duck," to cheat or deceive someone; it has come to mean in English a _false story_, an _unfounded rumor_. 
"Bob just told me there was an earthquake in California today, but I think it's a CANARD: it would have been on the news if it had actually happened." 
"Joel keeps us endlessly entertained with his tales of adventure: they're probably all CANARDS, but it doesn't matter."

questions.prompt: Are most professional sports stadiums CAPACIOUS?
Would most people consider being an astronaut a PROSAIC occupation?
Is a QUERULOUS person likely to be considered easy-going?
Is laziness a characteristic of a RESTIVE person?
Is something that is VIRULENT fun to have?
Would a CONFITURE generally contain sugar?
Would an argumentative person be likely to DEMUR frequently?
Would a MENDACIOUS person tell lies?
Could antigovernment speeches that urge the people to riot be considered SEDITIOUS?
Would a belligerent man be likely to EFFACE himself?
Is a pastoral setting INIMICAL to tranquility?
Their demands are CAPACIOUS; we will never agree to them.
A thick layer of soot had made the window practically DIAPHANOUS.
Keats's "Ode on a Grecian Urn" is one of the most PROSAIC lyrics in the language.
The couple's QUERULOUS remarks about the food and the service infuriated the waiter.
The RESTIVE medicine is supposed to help him sleep.
The SYCOPHANT told the Duke he was the wisest nobleman in the land.
The author was upset by the VIRULENT criticism of his novel.
They had roast duck for a main course and specially prepared CONFITURES for dessert.
They DEMURRED us for wanting to do things our own way.
Her habitual EQUANIMITY was shattered by the news of her husband's death.
Jim's MENDACITY belied his pleasing appearance.
The PENURIOUS man served his guests nothing but thin soup and stale bread.
They were sentenced to ten years in prison for their SEDITIOUS utterances.
The threat of a common enemy forced the inhabitants of the valley to EFFACE their internal differences.
We may never again see the equal of this INIMICAL young pianist.

CAPACIOUS.deftext:
roomy, spacious 
CAPACIOUS comes from a Latin word meaning to _contain_; it is also the source of the English word _capacity_. CAPACIOUS means _roomy_, "able to contain a lot." 
"The flower-filled hall was so CAPACIOUS that I felt as if I were in a meadow." 
"The CAPACIOUS pockets in the man's coat contained everything from candy to an old Boy Scout manual." 
CAPACIOUS can also be used in an extended sense. 
"Her CAPACIOUS mind absorbs everything she reads and sees; where she stores all that information is a mystery." 
Many people wrongly choose _greedy_ as the answer on the Pretest, perhaps confusing CAPACIOUS with _rapacious_. See _rapacious_ in Chapter 4.

DIAPHANOUS.deftext:
translucent, transparent 
Something that is DIAPHANOUS allows light to shine through it, usually because of its delicate, sheer texture. 
"I could make out her beautiful features beneath the DIAPHANOUS veil." 
"In the painting you could see the sunlight through the DIAPHANOUS wings of the angel." 
Often the word is used in a somewhat general sense, with the emphasis on the delicacy of form and texture. 
"The movie made you feel as if you were in an ethereal, DIAPHANOUS fairyland, floating through gossamer clouds."

PROSAIC.deftext:
like prose; commonplace, matter-of-fact, ordinary, dull 
_Prose_ is ordinary speech or writing, as distinguished from poetry. PROSAIC is the adjective from _prose_. See _-ic_ under Suffixes. PROSAIC emphasizes the dull, commonplace character of prose, and can be used about anything that has this quality. 
"The book is a very PROSAIC summary of his life, merely listing names and dates and places without trying to explain the man's greatness." 
"Luciano Pavarotti left his PROSAIC job as an insurance salesman to become a famous opera singer." 
Twice as many people who take the Pretest think PROSAIC means _poetic_ as think it means _commonplace_. These people are probably familiar with the phrase "prose and poetry," but have not learned the distinction between the two.

QUERULOUS.deftext:
complaining, irritable, peevish 
QUERULOUS comes from a Latin word meaning to _complain_. A QUERULOUS person is full of complaints, particularly petty ones. 
"The head of the complaint department soon tired of dealing with QUERULOUS customers." 
"He is so QUERULOUS, always finding fault with trivial shortcomings. He certainly isn't fun to be with." 
QUERULOUS is also used about one's tone and manner and means "expressing complaints." 
"Even when she was being polite her tone was QUERULOUS, as if she were irritated by something."

RESTIVE.deftext:
restless, unruly, uneasy, refractory 
The original meaning of RESTIVE is "resisting control," _balky_, and it is still used in this sense. More commonly, however, it is now used as a synonym of _restless_, especially when the restlessness is a result of an attempt to restrict or control. 
"The horse became RESTIVE whenever anyone tried to put a bridle on it." 
"The audience became RESTIVE as the intermission lengthened and the play did not resume." 
"By three o'clock the children were so RESTIVE that the teacher could no longer keep them in their seats." 
_Quiet_ is a very common answer on the Pretest. It is probably chosen by people who think RESTIVE has something to do with _resting_. The two words are not related, however, and _quiet_ is virtually an opposite of RESTIVE.

SYCOPHANCY.deftext:
servility, toadying, base flattery 
A SYCOPHANT is a person who attempts to gain favor by lavishing flattery and attention on a person who has wealth or power. 
"Wherever he went the king was surrounded by SYCOPHANTS who catered to his every whim in the hope that he would reward them." 
SYCOPHANCY is the quality or practice of a SYCOPHANT. 
"Bill's SYCOPHANCY toward the coach won't get him anywhere. It's what he does during the game that counts." 
"The SYCOPHANCY of the courtiers disgusted the knight, and he soon left the court to serve another nobleman." 
Other forms of the word: SYCOPHANT, n. SYCOPHANTIC, adj.

VIRULENT.deftext:
poisonous, venomous 
VIRULENT comes from the Latin word _virus_, the source also of the English word _virus_. See _-ent_ under Suffixes. In English today VIRULENT refers to the destructive and malignant qualities of a disease or poison. 
"This VIRULENT form of the flu caused thousands of deaths last winter." 
In its extended use, VIRULENT refers to anything that is particularly bitter, hostile, or hateful. 
"The mudslinging between the opponents became increasingly VIRULENT: terrible things were said on both sides." 
"Mr. Jones has a VIRULENT hatred of cats; he has been known to poison them." 
_Persistent_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer. It is perhaps chosen by people who know that VIRULENT diseases are serious and long-term. The meaning of VIRULENT, however, is _poisonous_. 
Other forms of the word: VIRULENCE, n.

CONFITURE.deftext:
a jam, preserve, confection 
A CONFITURE is preserved fruit; it is a rather literary synonym for _jam_. 
"Pierre always had a dish of raspberry CONFITURE with his croissant." 
"Martha spends hours in the kitchen every fall, canning vegetables and preparing CONFITURES."

DEMUR.deftext:
to object, take exception 
To DEMUR to something is to object to it, to be reluctant to agree to it. It is usually used with _to_ or _at_. 
"Bill wanted to DEMUR to the proposition, but everybody else seemed to agree with it." 
"Many of the councilmen DEMURRED at the suggestion that gambling casinos be built in their town." 
"Sarah wanted to have lunch at Rick's, but Joe DEMURRED, remembering how bad the food had been there." 
_Retreat_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps because of a vague association with the unrelated adjective _demure_. 
Other forms of the word: DEMURRAL, n.

EQUANIMITY.deftext:
composure, calmness, sangfroid 
EQUANIMITY comes from a Latin word meaning _even-tempered_. The _equ_ root, meaning _equal_ or _even_, is also found in words like _equation_ and _equality_. EQUANAMITY is the characteristic of being even-tempered, of possessing mental and emotional balance. Someone with EQUANIMITY is not easily upset or excited. 
"Even the children's fighting could not disturb Harold's EQUANIMITY. He merely inquired what the matter was." 
"The pressures of her job caused Susan to lose her usual EQUANIMITY." 
"The teacher doesn't possess enough EQUANIMITY to face the rowdy students day after day without losing her temper." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _fairness_, perhaps because the _equ_ root suggests the words _equality_ or _equitability_.

MENDACIOUS.deftext:
lying, untruthful, dishonest 
MENDACIOUS means lying. It is used particularly about people who are habitually untruthful. 
"The MENDACIOUS boy told everyone a different story about how the house had caught fire." 
It is also used about what such a person says. 
"The politician called the newspaper report completely MENDACIOUS. He said he had never taken a bribe in his life." 
The noun form of MENDACIOUS is MENDACITY, which means "habitual lying." 
"Her reputation for MENDACITY makes it difficult for me to believe her accusations." 
Other forms of the word: MENDACITY, n.

PENURIOUS.deftext:
needy, poor; stingy, miserly 
PENURIOUS means needy, very poor. Someone who is PENURIOUS is oppressed by a lack of money. 
"The man is so PENURIOUS that he has to sleep outside in a box." 
"The PENURIOUS conditions of life among migrant workers often mean one meal a day and ragged clothes." 
PENURIOUS can also mean _stingy_. The implication is that someone is so miserly that he or she appears poor. 
"The lady is so PENURIOUS that even though she has a small fortune, she wears the same old coat winter and summer and eats out of garbage cans." 
Other forms of the word: PENURY, n.

SEDITIOUS.deftext:
rebellious, insubordinate, mutinous 
SEDITION is conduct that incites rebellion against the government. The difference between SEDITION and _treason_ is that treason is the actual act of trying to overthrow the government or aiding the enemy; a speech or book that promotes this kind of act would be an example of SEDITION. SEDITIOUS is the adjective from SEDITION; see _-ous_ under Suffixes. 
"The government accused him of SEDITION because of his fiery speeches attacking its leaders." 
"Her SEDITIOUS pamphlets were secretly circulated among the opponents of the government." 
"The dictator decreed that any newspaper article critical of him would be considered SEDITIOUS." 
Other forms of the word: SEDITION, n.

EFFACE.deftext:
to wipe out, obliterate, erase 
To EFFACE something is to remove all visible evidence of its existence. 
"Over the centuries the weather gradually EFFACED the inscription on the tomb." 
The word is often used figuratively. 
"Bob's new wife completely redecorated his house in an effort to EFFACE the memory of his unfortunate first marriage." 
To EFFACE oneself is to act inconspicuously, to avoid drawing attention to oneself. This meaning of the word is also found in the adjective SELF-EFFACING. 
"In public the prince always EFFACED himself so that attention would be centered on the queen." 
Other forms of the word: EFFACEMENT, n.

INIMICAL.deftext:
hostile, antagonistic; harmful, adverse 
INIMICAL is related to the word _enemy_. Its basic meaning in English is _unfriendly_, _hostile_. 
"The man's INIMICAL stare told us he certainly wasn't going to do us any favors." 
Usually, however, INIMICAL is used about things or activities and means "harmful in its effects." In this sense INIMICAL is usually followed by _to_. 
"Eating huge amounts of candy is INIMICAL to good health." 
"The president claims that raising taxes is INIMICAL to the interests of the average citizen." 
_Fake_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps because people make a vague connection with _inimitable_, which means "not able to be imitated."

Would a PHLEGMATIC person be demonstrative?

Neither side had much to say to the other, so the COLLOQUY had to be considered a failure.
Few Americans would like to see Communist HEGEMONY in Western Europe.
It is perfectly OSTENSIBLE of you not to want to come with us.

The nation's PROFLIGATE use of its oil supplies caused a severe shortage.
The PUTATIVE scientific breakthrough turned out to be nothing more than a hoax.
Mary doesn't mind her brother's RAILLERY because she knows he loves her.
The interviewer was used to people DISSEMBLING, and quickly spotted the man as a phony.
Mrs. Porter EXPATIATED us to try her brownies.
The sharp blade of the sword MACERATED his arm.
Everyone became involved in the MAELSTROM of controversy surrounding the building of the new power plant.

NASCENT.deftext:
beginning to exist, incipient 
NASCENT comes from a Latin word meaning to _be born_, and is related to such words as _natal_ and _native_. Something that is NASCENT is just beginning to be born, is coming into existence. 
"Jane's parents try to encourage her NASCENT interest in classical music." 
"The NASCENT solar energy industry was greatly aided by the oil shortage." 
"The country's NASCENT war fever died down after the destruction of its fleet." 
_Changing_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest. Something that is NASCENT is changing, but in a particular way: it is beginning to exist. 
Other forms of the word: NASCENCE, n. NASCENCY, n.

PHLEGMATIC.deftext:
unemotional, impassive, undemonstrative 
PHLEGMATIC is the adjective from PHLEGM (flem), which today means specifically _mucus_, but in medieval theory was considered one of the four "humors" or fluids of the body that were supposed to determine a person's disposition. PHLEGM was thought to cause sluggishness and lack of emotion. PHLEGMATIC therefore means "difficult to arouse," _impassive_, _sluggish_. 
"Bob's aloofness makes him seem PHLEGMATIC but really he is only shy." 
"The lofty spires of the cathedral thrilled Peggy, but left her more PHLEGMATIC husband totally unmoved." 
"The speaker hoped to arouse his audience's passions, and was disappointed by its PHLEGMATIC response." 
_Sickly_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, probably because people are misled by the PHLEGM part of PHLEGMATIC. 
Other forms of the word: PHLEGM, n.

PRECIPITOUS.deftext:
extremely steep 
PRECIPITOUS is the adjective from PRECIPICE, a cliff with a vertical face. It means _steep_, nearly vertical. 
"The mountain presented a PRECIPITOUS wall of rock on its eastern face." 
"We realized that we had come to the edge of the cliff and had nearly had a PRECIPITOUS fall." 
_Dangerous_ and _threatening_ are two very common wrong answers. Something that is PRECIPITOUS is probably both dangerous and threatening, but PRECIPITOUS means only _steep_. 
Other forms of the word: PRECIPICE, n.

BADINAGE.deftext:
banter, light repartee 
BADINAGE is lighthearted, playful banter, playful kidding. 
"Their BADINAGE was very entertaining: witty puns and playful insults bounced back and forth like tennis balls." 
"Even if they don't look alike, the BADINAGE in their conversation marks them as brother and sister: only siblings are so affectionately disrespectful."

COLLOQUY.deftext:
a conference, formal conversation 
COLLOQUY comes from a Latin word meaning to _speak together_. See _col-_ under Prefixes. The _loqu_ root is also found in such words as _colloquial_ and _loquacity_. A COLLOQUY is a conversation or a dialogue, especially one that is serious or at a high level. 
"The COLLOQUY between the heads of state went on for several hours." 
"The labor-management COLLOQUY was amicable, but failed to resolve their differences." 
_Expression_ and _lecture _are both commonly chosen wrong answers. Both deal with speaking, but neither involve speaking _together_.

HEGEMONY.deftext:
dominance, predominance, leadership 
HEGEMONY is dominance or preponderant influence. The word is used especially about the dominance of one country over others in a particular area. 
"China sought to establish its HEGEMONY in Southeast Asia." 
"Athens and Sparta vied for HEGEMONY in ancient Greece." 
"The tribe's HEGEMONY in the area crumbled with the arrival of the European colonists."

OSTENSIBLE.deftext:
pretended, seeming, apparent 
OSTENSIBLE comes from a Latin word meaning to _show_; it is related to the word _ostentation_, which is boastful showiness. OSTENSIBLE originally meant "open to view; able to be seen," but in modern use it suggests that what is apparent on the surface is not true underneath, that there is a hidden purpose or character to something. 
"Ralph's OSTENSIBLE business was television repair, but he was really a smuggler." 
"The OSTENSIBLE purpose of her visit was to welcome them to the neighborhood, but she really just wanted to see how rich they were." 
"He is OSTENSIBLY an accountant, but in fact he is a daring secret agent." 
_Reasonable_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps because it sounds somewhat like OSTENSIBLE, perhaps because something that is OSTENSIBLE appears reasonable, even if it is not true.

PERIPATETIC.deftext:
walking about, itinerant 
The Greek philosopher Aristotle taught his followers while walking about the Lyceum, a school of ancient Athens. These followers came to be called PERIPATETICS, after a Greek word meaning "to walk around," and the word was also applied to Aristotle's philosophy. The word then came to be used about anyone who wanders about, especially in connection with his or her calling. 
"The PERIPATETIC actors wandered through the countryside, performing in every town they entered." 
The word can also be used about something that is carried on while one moves about. 
"The two travelers had a PERIPATETIC debate about the merits of walking versus riding a bicycle."

PROFLIGATE.deftext:
extravagant, wasteful; dissolute, immoral, abandoned 
Someone who is PROFLIGATE is shamelessly immoral, totally given over to dissipation. 
"The PROFLIGATE young noblemen wasted their lives gambling and drinking." 
Very often the word refers only to a person's spending and wastefulness, and means "recklessly extravagant." 
"The heiress was so PROFLIGATE that she soon spent her inheritance." 
"The mayor's PROFLIGATE spending ultimately meant that taxes had to be increased." 
PROFLIGATE is also a noun, meaning "an extravagant or immoral person." 
"These young PROFLIGATES will never come to anything unless they mend their ways." 
Other forms of the word: PROFLIGACY, n.

PUTATIVE.deftext:
supposed, reputed 
PUTATIVE comes from a Latin word meaning "to consider," the source also of the English words _dispute_, _impute_, _repute_, and _compute_. PUTATIVE refers to something that is commonly believed but is not proven, so that the speaker has some doubts about its truth: something that is _supposed_ to be true, but not assured to be. 
"This secretary has good references, but her PUTATIVE skills are nonexistent: she can't type or do shorthand." 
"Many people were executed even though their PUTATIVE treasons had been only half-baked dreams of revolution." 
"Shakespeare is the PUTATIVE author of the play, but the evidence in his favor is somewhat contradictory."

RAILLERY.deftext:
banter, good-natured teasing 
RAILLERY is related to the verb to _rail_, which means to _speak bitterly_, to _abuse verbally_. RAILLERY is softer; it is good-natured teasing, pleasant banter with a touch of sarcasm. 
"The throwing of the bride's bouquet was accompanied by some RAILLERY about old maids." 
"The RAILLERY of his buddies on his sixtieth birthday bothered the man not at all." 
"The two young men got into a fight when what had started as good-natured RAILLERY took on a sharper edge."

DISSEMBLE.deftext:
to disguise, pretend, feign 
To DISSEMBLE is to conceal one's true identity or purpose, usually in order to deceive someone. 
"When asked why he was in the off-limits area, the spy was forced to DISSEMBLE and said that he had gotten lost." 
When used as a transitive verb, DISSEMBLE means "to cloak the true appearance of," to _disguise_. 
"She DISSEMBLED her anxiety by laughing gaily and trying to appear unconcerned." 
"It was impossible to DISSEMBLE his exultation at the defeat of his enemy." 
_Destroy_ is a commonly chosen wrong answer, possibly because of confusion with the word _disassemble_.

EXPATIATE.deftext:
to elaborate, dilate, discourse 
EXPATIATE is related to the words _space_ and _spatial_. To EXPATIATE was originally used about physical movement and meant "to move about freely." The word is now used only in a figurative sense about wide-ranging and lengthy speech. 
"The orator EXPATIATED on the virtues of ancient Athens." 
"The teacher EXPATIATED upon the difference between participles and gerunds." 
"Realizing he had an hour to fill, the speaker had to EXPATIATE at great length upon the topic." 
Other forms of the word: EXPATIATION, n.

MACERATE.deftext:
to soften, to emaciate 
To MACERATE something is to soften it or to separate it into its parts by steeping it in a liquid. 
"The process involves MACERATING the tree bark in water for several hours." 
"The tough grass MACERATED in the cow's stomach." 
The word is also occasionally used about the wasting away of a person's flesh due to fasting, worry, or illness. 
"His long suffering has MACERATED his flesh, and now he is nothing but skin and bones."

MAELSTROM.deftext:
a whirlpool 
MAELSTROM was originally the name of a very powerful whirlpool off the coast of Norway; now it is applied to any especially violent or dangerous whirlpool. 
"The ship's captain awoke from a nightmare in which his ship was being relentlessly sucked into a MAELSTROM." 
In an extended sense, MAELSTROM is used about any turbulent situation that is like a whirlpool, drawing people into it. 
"Even the peaceful Quakers were caught up in the MAELSTROM of the war, as marauding soldiers burned their barns and pillaged their farms." 
"The exciting final inning of the game drew even the quietest spectators into the MAELSTROM of excitement."
