questions.prompt: Do timid people tend to be TRUCULENT?
Is a bold person likely to possess TEMERITY?
Would a minister ADJURE people not to lie?
Do most people find ASPERITY pleasant?
Would a person who lies GAINSAY something that is true?
Would an implacable foe want to EXTIRPATE his enemy?
Would an INGENUOUS person try to deceive people?
Would INSOUCIANT people usually possess self-confidence?
Is a SANGUINE person likely to be anguished?
Is laziness a characteristic of a SEDULOUS person?
Would someone who is capable of deep thought be SENTIENT?
Is a river in SPATE likely to be dangerous?
These plans are the result of deep RATIOCINATION by some of our finest minds.
The student's TRUCULENT behavior quickly exasperated the teacher.
The NACREOUS wolves advanced across the clearing toward him.
Phil lacked the TEMERITY to object to his boss's outrageous demands.
Sal ADJURED her for putting catsup on her fried egg.
The ASPERITY with which she gazed at our work suggested that we were in for a tongue-lashing.
The professor GAINSAID to us that we would have to try harder on the final.
The military government vowed to EXTIRPATE all of its opponents.
This INGENUOUS new invention will revolutionize photography.
The INSOUCIANT secretary didn't seem to care what her boss thought of her.
The judge sent the mother to jail for her SANGUINE abuse of her children.
It was SEDULOUS of her to refuse to see us.
Benjamin Franklin's SENTIENT maxims are still widely quoted.
The baseball player received the SOBRIQUET "Stick" because he was so thin.
The movie was really popular at first, but attendance declined to a SPATE after a few weeks.

RATIOCINATION.deftext:
reasoning 
RATIOCINATION is the process of logical thinking. The word comes from the same Latin root as _rational_. It usually suggests an extended process, not simply a deduction reached from a set of facts. 
"Carla didn't reach the correct solution by guesswork, but by pure RATIOCINATION." 
"The philosopher's RATIOCINATIONS were interrupted by the arrival of a visitor." 
"Sidney was not capable of prolonged RATIOCINATION. He said hard thinking gave him a headache." 
_Dividing_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, probably because people are attracted to the _ratio_ part of the word. 
Other forms of the word: RATIOCINATE, v. RATIOCINATIVE, adj.

TRUCULENT.deftext:
fierce, belligerent, pugnacious 
TRUCULENT means "having a fierce appearance or disposition." It is used about people who are always ready to fight or bully others. 
"The TRUCULENT drunk bellowed that he could beat up anybody in the bar." 
"The TRUCULENT hockey team likes nothing more than to get in a brawl with its opponent." 
"Despite its small size, the country is quite TRUCULENT, and is always threatening to invade its neighbors." 
Other forms of the word: TRUCULENCE, n.

NACREOUS.deftext:
pearly, lustrous 
NACRE is mother-of-pearl, the hard, luminous, colorful substance that forms the inside layer of the pearl oyster shell and other sea-animal shells. Something that is NACREOUS is pearl-like, lustrous. 
"The shell that he found on the beach was rough and encrusted on the outside, but smooth and NACREOUS within." 
"The blue veins just visible under the skin of her white throat lent it a beautiful NACREOUS quality."

TEMERITY.deftext:
rashness, effrontery, audacity 
TEMERITY is rash boldness, a reckless disregard of danger or opposition. The word often suggests presumptuousness. 
"The student had the TEMERITY to suggest that the professor didn't know what she was talking about." 
"It took a certain amount of TEMERITY for Bill to ignore his doctor's advice and run in the marathon." 
"Janet's TEMERITY in arguing with the president about company policy cost her her job." 
A related adjective is TEMERARIOUS, which means "presumptuously rash." 
TEMERITY appears to be difficult mostly because of confusion with _timidity_. _Cowardice_, an opposite, is a more popular choice on the Pretest than the correct answer, _rashness_. 
Other forms of the word: TEMERARIOUS, adj.

ADJURE.deftext:
command, enjoin, entreat 
To ADJURE is to command solemnly or earnestly. When the emphasis is placed on the earnestness of the command, ADJURE comes close to meaning _entreat_ or _beg_. 
"The missionary ADJURED his disciples to think less about the world and more about their work." 
"All of the new altarboys were ADJURED to pay strict attention during the service." 
"The guard ADJURED us not to touch the sculptures." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _criticize_, due perhaps to a confusion of ADJURE with _admonish_. 
Other forms of the word: ADJURATION, n.

ASPERITY.deftext:
harshness, acerbity, severity, irritability 
ASPERITY comes from a Latin word meaning _rough_. This root is also found in the word _exasperate_, which literally means to _make rough_, but is usually used about people's states of mind and means to _make irritable_, to _provoke_. ASPERITY can be used about the literal roughness of a surface, or of harsh sounds, but like _exasperate_ it is usually applied to people, and refers to harshness of temper or manner. 
"The company's spokesman said with some ASPERITY that it had never done anything illegal." 
"He regretted now the ASPERITY with which he had rejected their advice." 
"The ASPERITY of his manner made people nervous and a little frightened."

GAINSAY.deftext:
to deny, contradict 
To GAINSAY something is to dispute its truth, to deny it. It is a rather literary term, and is generally used in a negative construction. The past tense is GAINSAID. 
"Much as we dislike her, we cannot GAINSAY her right to inherit the house." 
"No one is attempting to GAINSAY the accuracy of your data; we merely question your interpretation of it." 
"Despite his shortcomings, he is a great man; that cannot be GAINSAID." 
_Suggest_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, probably influenced by the _say_ part of GAINSAY.

EXTIRPATE.deftext:
to annihilate, exterminate, root out 
The _tirp_ part of EXTIRPATE comes from a Latin word meaning _root_. The literal meaning of EXTIRPATE is to _root out_. See _ex-_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. The word usually suggests total destruction. 
"We must not only defeat the enemy, we must EXTIRPATE them." 
"Sharon was determined to EXTIRPATE the weeds from her garden, once and for all." 
"The missionaries were not successful in EXTIRPATING the devil worship among the natives." 
Other forms of the word: EXTIRPATION, n.

INGENUOUS.deftext:
naive, natural, artless 
INGENUOUS means _candid_, _open_, _simple_, _without pretense_. It implies a childlike inability to deceive, rather than a conscious choice not to deceive. It is applied both to people and their actions. 
"Even when he misbehaved, Billy's voluntary, INGENUOUS confession would endear him to his parents." 
"Diane is so INGENUOUS that it seems cruel to trick her like this." 
"When questioned about her whereabouts on the night of the murder, her INGENUOUS answer convinced the detectives of her innocence." 
More people choose _cunning_, a wrong answer, than _naive_, the right one, due no doubt to a confusion with the easier word _ingenious_.

INSOUCIANT.deftext:
carefree, unconcerned 
INSOUCIANT means "free from care or anxiety." The word is used with regard to people who don't care what kind of impression they make or how others respond to them. 
"Debbie's INSOUCIANT behavior at the party showed that she didn't mind shocking her hosts." 
"Jim INSOUCIANTLY asked the principal to hold his books for him while he tied his shoelace." 
"The INSOUCIANT young fellow wore whatever he liked and said whatever popped into his mind." 
_Disrespectful_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer. Often INSOUCIANT people may appear disrespectful, since they don't care what other people think of them, but the emphasis in the word is on this lack of concern, not the lack of respect. 
Other forms of the word: INSOUCIANCE, n.

SANGUINE.deftext:
hopeful, optimistic, confident 
SANGUINE comes from the Latin word for _blood_, and is still used in English to mean _bloody_ or _blood-covered_. Its most common use, however, derives from the medieval theory that a person's general disposition was determined by the quantities of four fluids in his or her body. If blood predominated, the person was supposed to be spirited and passionate. From this has come SANGUINE's current meaning of "cheerfully optimistic," _hopeful_. Sometimes the word suggests over-optimism or confidence that is misplaced. 
"Despite all his misfortunes, Mr. Micawber remained SANGUINE about his prospects for the future." 
"I am not SANGUINE about my chances of getting into a good college." 
"Gail's SANGUINE disposition led her to think that losing her job was just a temporary setback." 
_Cruel_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, probably due to the connection of SANGUINE with blood.

SEDULOUS.deftext:
diligent, industrious 
SEDULOUS means _industrious_, and implies that a person is working hard and persistently at accomplishing something. 
"He is not a genius, but his SEDULOUS efforts earn him very good grades." 
"SEDULOUS attention to detail marks Joe as a clerk who takes his job seriously." 
"The nurse is SEDULOUS in carrying out her duties; nothing remains undone at the end of her shift."

SENTIENT.deftext:
conscious, aware, capable of feeling 
SENTIENT is from a Latin word meaning to _feel_; it is related to words like _sensitive_ and _sensuous_ that also have to do with feeling and the senses. SENTIENT means "capable of perceiving through the senses." It is applied to living beings, like animals or humans, who have some form of consciousness. 
"He could not believe there was a SENTIENT creature that didn't know who had won the World Series." 
"She thought rocks were SENTIENT and wouldn't kick any for fear of hurting them." 
_Wise_ is a commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps due to confusion with _sententious_, which means _pithy_, "full of aphorisms." 
Other forms of the word: SENTIENCE, n.

SOBRIQUET.deftext:
a nickname 
SOBRIQUET is sometimes spelled SOUBRIQUET. 
A SOBRIQUET is a nickname, especially one that is humorous, affectionate, or picturesque. 
"Babe Ruth's tremendous batting prowess earned him the SOBRIQUET 'The Sultan of Swat.'" 
"Lincoln's SOBRIQUET 'Honest Abe' is known by every American schoolchild." 
"After losing his hat in a gust of wind, Bill decided that 'The Windy City' was an appropriate SOBRIQUET for Chicago."

SPATE.deftext:
a flood, outpouring, deluge 
A SPATE is literally a stream or river that has become full and turbulent due to melting snow or heavy rains. In this sense, the word is often used in the phrase "in SPATE" or "in full SPATE." Usually the word is used in a figurative sense about any kind of sudden rush or outpouring. 
"The news that the prince was to be married produced a SPATE of books and articles on the royal family." 
"There was a SPATE of phone calls at the TV station protesting the decision not to televise the basketball game." 
This word is difficult because many people think a SPATE is a lot slower than it really is. _Trickle_ is almost as common an answer on the Pretest as the correct answer, _flood_.

questions.prompt: Is a CALLOW youth likely to be extremely self-confident?
Is a timid person likely to be CONTUMACIOUS?
Could an OFFICIOUS person be annoying?
Would a PROLIX person use a great many words?
Can the president of a company issue a UKASE?
Would an extravagant person feel an ANIMUS against spending money?
Would an ATELIER generally be tiny?
Is it easy to get rid of a PERTINACIOUS admirer?
Is a sloppy person likely to be PUNCTILIOUS?
Are belligerent nations interested in COMITY?
No one could gainsay the principal's APPOSITE remarks about the need for discipline.
The CALLOW young actress was afraid to ask the director for an audition.
The judge deplored their CONTUMACY and threatened to hold them in contempt of court.
The accountant's CUPIDITY led him to steal thousands of dollars in company funds.
The OFFICIOUS results showed neither candidate gaining a majority.
Because of space limitations, the editor told the writer to avoid PROLIXITY.
The workers resent these management UKASES; they want some say in how the company is run.
His ANIMUS toward foreigners is an unfortunate byproduct of his experiences during the war.
The apprentices crowded into the ATELIER to see the famous sculptor at work.
Her happiness proved to be EVANESCENT; in a few months tragedy struck.
It is PERTINACIOUS of you to suggest that I am bigoted.
The animal is smooth-skinned except for small PILEOUS areas on each paw.
He was PUNCTILIOUS about winning the contest; he simply said he deserved it.
These new trade restrictions will certainly not increase COMITY among the affected nations.

APPOSITE.deftext:
fitting, suitable, appropriate 
APPOSITE means _fitting_, _apt_, _pertinent_. The word is usually applied to something, like a quotation, that is strikingly appropriate for a particular situation. 
"I thought the dean's remarks about belt-tightening were extremely APPOSITE, given the recent release of this year's budget figures." 
"The text was reasonably clear, but the photographs were not particularly APPOSITE." 
"We thought it was an APPOSITE decision to dedicate the new gym on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the dedication of the old gym."

CALLOW.deftext:
immature, inexperienced, unsophisticated 
CALLOW comes from an Anglo-Saxon word meaning _bald_, which would seem to be almost an opposite of its current meaning, _immature_. Originally, however, the word was applied to birds, and referred to the lack of feathers of a young bird. CALLOW people, then, are like birds who haven't learned to fly; they are naive and inexperienced in the ways of the world. 
"The upperclassmen at the school often take advantage of the CALLOW freshmen." 
"The CALLOW recruits were hopelessly inept at being soldiers." 
_Insincere_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest, perhaps because CALLOW sounds like such negative words as _callous_ and _shallow_.

CONTUMACIOUS.deftext:
rebellious, insubordinate 
A CONTUMACIOUS person is stubbornly, and often contemptuously, resistant to authority. The word is especially used about resistance to legal authority, for example by ignoring a summons. 
"The CONTUMACIOUS rebels scoffed at the indictments, saying they were nothing but worthless pieces of paper." 
"When asked if he would abide by the committee's decision, his CONTUMACIOUS reply was 'Nuts!'." 
The noun form of CONTUMACIOUS is CONTUMACY. 
"His CONTUMACY in refusing to turn over the documents to the court is reprehensible and illegal." 
Other forms of the word: CONTUMACY, n.

COUNTERPANE.deftext:
a bedspread, coverlet 
COUNTERPANE is an old-fashioned word for bedspread. 
"When you make the bed, turn the COUNTERPANE down neatly under the pillow." 
"The bed was covered with a beautiful needlepoint COUNTERPANE." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _window_, probably a guess based on the _pane_ part of COUNTERPANE.

CUPIDITY.deftext:
greed, avarice, rapacity 
Cupid was the Roman god of love. Both _Cupid_ and CUPIDITY come from a Latin word meaning _desire_. See _-ity_ under Suffixes. CUPIDITY, however, is only used about desire for wealth or possessions, _greed_. 
"His CUPIDITY is only exceeded by his stupidity. He is not smart enough to know how to obtain the wealth he longs for." 
"Her greatest fault is her CUPIDITY; she wants to own everything she sees in the jewelry store." 
The wrong answer _love_ attracts people who are familiar with Cupid, but don't know the meaning of CUPIDITY.

OFFICIOUS.deftext:
meddlesome, impertinent, intrusive 
One of the many meanings of the word OFFICE is "an act performed for another," a _service_ or _favor_. 
"Through the kind OFFICES of a friend she was able to find transportation to the meeting." 
OFFICIOUS is an adjective from this sense of OFFICE. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. OFFICIOUS originally meant simply "eager to offer one's services." Now, however, it always contains the sense that this offer is unwanted and intrusive. 
"The president's OFFICIOUS meddling made a mess out of the company volleyball tournament." 
"The OFFICIOUS nurse wants to have a hand in every decision made on the ward." 
_Pompous_ is a more common answer than the correct synonym, _meddlesome_. An OFFICIOUS person may seem pompous, but pomposity is not involved in the meaning of the word.

PROLIX.deftext:
wordy, verbose, long-winded 
A PROLIX person speaks or writes at such great length as to be tedious. A PROLIX work is one that is too wordy. 
"It seemed as if the PROLIX after-dinner speaker would go on forever." 
"My teacher hasn't assigned many books, but each one is so PROLIX I'm afraid I won't get through any of them." 
"Your essay is too PROLIX; you go on for ten pages to state what you could have said in one." 
Other forms of the word: PROLIXITY, n.

UKASE.deftext:
an edict, decree 
UKASE is one of the few words in English that come from the Russian. A UKASE was a proclamation or order of the czar that had the force of law. In English, a UKASE is any edict or decree that is backed by strong authority and a presumption that it will be obeyed. 
"When Mr. Phipps issued a UKASE, no one dared disobey; he was the absolute authority in the company." 
"The citizens rebelled against the dictator's government by UKASE, and insisted that they be able to elect representatives who could vote on laws."

ANIMUS.deftext:
hostility, animosity, enmity 
ANIMUS is the Latin word for _soul_. In English it can be used in a similar way to mean _spirit_ or _imagination_, but it is generally used in a narrower sense to mean "a spirit of ill will," _hostility_. It is similar to _animosity_, which comes from the same Latin source, except that an ANIMUS is more deep-seated and personal. 
"The defendant's ANIMUS toward the lawyer was evident in the short, surly answers he gave." 
"It is difficult to overcome the children's ANIMUS toward classical music." 
"Her ANIMUS toward her ex-husband was so strong that no one mentioned his name in her presence."

ATELIER.deftext:
a workshop, artist's studio 
Note the pronunciation: ATELIER is from the French, and keeps its French pronunciation. An ATELIER is an artist's studio or a workroom where students or apprentices of an artist work. 
"The painter's ATELIER has a skylight so that he gets natural light." 
"The huge mural covered one wall of the ATELIER; dozens of students worked on little pieces of it." 
More people choose _garret_, a wrong answer, than _workshop_, the right one. This could be due to a confusion with _attic_, or _garret_ may be chosen by people who know that an ATELIER is usually at the top of a building, without knowing precisely what it is.

EVANESCENT.deftext:
vanishing, fleeting, impermanent 
Something that is EVANESCENT exists only for a short time and then vanishes. The word usually implies that this brief existence is due to the object's delicacy and fragility. EVANESCENT is used about both physical objects and nonphysical states like fame. 
"Her dreams were so EVANESCENT that she couldn't remember them, and was left only with uncertain memories of loveliness." 
"The EVANESCENT morning mist drifted up from the river and vanished in the sunlight." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _sparkling_. This is probably due to a confusion with _effervescent_. 
Other forms of the word: EVANESCE, v. EVANESCENCE, n.

PERTINACIOUS.deftext:
obstinate, stubborn, persistent 
PERTINACIOUS is related to the word _tenacious_. Both come from a Latin word meaning to _hold_ and are used about people who hold fast to a purpose or belief. But while _tenacious_ is usually used in a positive sense, PERTINACIOUS has a negative connotation; it is used about people who are stubbornly persistent, who annoy others with their doggedness. 
"The PERTINACIOUS derelict followed me down the street, asking again and again for money." 
"The guide PERTINACIOUSLY insisted we were heading east, even when the sun began to set in front of us." 
"The boy's PERTINACIOUS curiosity exhausted us and then started to irritate us." 
_Rude_ is a commonly chosen wrong answer, probably due to confusion with _impertinent_. 
Other forms of the word: PERTINACITY, n.

PILEOUS.deftext:
hairy, furry 
PILEOUS and the similar adjective _pilose_ both come from a Latin word for _hair_, and mean _hairy_. The words particularly refer to hair with a soft texture. Another word from this source is _pile_, the soft compact surface texture of certain kinds of carpets. 
"He was startled awake when he reached over and embraced something very PILEOUS, but it was only his daughter's huge teddy bear." 
"Tarantulas have PILEOUS bodies that, along with their large size, make them quite gruesome."

PUNCTILIOUS.deftext:
attentive to fine points, careful, precise, scrupulous 
PUNCTILIOUS and its related noun PUNCTILIO come from Italian and Spanish words meaning "a small point." A PUNCTILIO is a fine point of behavior or etiquette. 
"He had no use for the PUNCTILIOS of these stuffy people, so he said and did whatever he pleased." 
PUNCTILIOUS means "attentive to fine points" and would be used about a person who is careful to observe the niceties of formal behavior. Often the word suggests excessive attention to these fine points. 
"Mrs. Andrews is PUNCTILIOUS about following the etiquette books in every detail when she gives a party." 
"The PUNCTILIOUS expert is always correcting everyone's grammar." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _pompous_, possibly because PUNCTILIOUS people seem pompous and arrogant, possibly because of confusion with the word _supercilious_, which means _haughty_, _disdainful_. See _supercilious_ in Chapter 4. 
Other forms of the word: PUNCTILIO, n.

COMITY.deftext:
civility, mutual courtesy 
COMITY is a rather formal word for _civility_. It is often used to refer to courteous relations between countries or heads of state, as in "COMITY of nations." 
"We must strive for COMITY; if nothing else, we should treat each other with respect." 
"The COMITY of the two leaders was based on a sincere desire for world peace; to this end, they started by treating one another civilly." 
"As it became clear that the little principality was not going to repay its debts soon, the COMITY it shared with larger states began to wear thin."

questions.prompt: Is self-denial an example of TURPITUDE?
Would a diligent person be DILATORY?
Can the flu cause a person to feel FEBRILE?
Do authors like to have their books contain LACUNAE?
Is the Bill of Rights NUGATORY?
Would giving a sermon be a SACERDOTAL duty?
Would a SATURNINE person enjoy a comedy show?
Everyone admires the absolute TURPITUDE of the fine young man.
After Rich's parents gave him a Cadillac for his birthday, it was CAPTIOUS of him to complain about the color.
It is DILATORY that we avoid being caught tonight.
He is just an EPIGONE, with no distinctive voice or ideas of his own.
The FEBRILE pace of Mary's life often makes her tired and irritable.
This piece of steak has gone bad; it is no longer FRIABLE.
Erosion has caused several LACUNAS to appear in the ancient tomb inscription.
We are BENIGHTED that you could be with us today.
Several MORIBUND bills were given a new life when Congress returned from its recess.
The committee's GELID response to our proposal convinced us it would never be accepted.
The DOYEN of American chefs sums up his knowledge of cuisine in this new book.
The effect of the lawyer's closing argument was NUGATORY; the jury had already made up its mind.
The RECALCITRANT students absolutely refused to take the test.
Once he was admitted to the priesthood he learned the secret SACERDOTAL language.
The SATURNINE man cheerfully gave his help to anyone who asked for it.

TURPITUDE.deftext:
depravity, baseness 
TURPITUDE is baseness or vileness. It is often used in the phrase "moral TURPITUDE." 
"Hester Prynne was accused of moral TURPITUDE when the town discovered she was pregnant without being married." 
"The governor said his opponent's TURPITUDE made him unfit to serve in office." 
TURPITUDE is also occasionally used about a base or vile act. 
"The preacher said that such TURPITUDES would not go unpunished in the hereafter." 
TURPITUDE is thought to mean _righteousness_ by a large proportion of the people taking the Pretest, due to confusion of TURPITUDE with _rectitude_.

CAPTIOUS.deftext:
faultfinding, carping 
CAPTIOUS means _faultfinding_; someone who is CAPTIOUS is hard to please, likes to make petty criticisms. 
"Pamela was annoyed by John's CAPTIOUS criticism of her every utterance." 
"The man is so CAPTIOUS that his valets leave one after another, fed up with his constant nitpicking." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _entrancing_, probably due to a confusion of CAPTIOUS with _captivating_.

DILATORY.deftext:
slow, tardy, causing delay 
DILATORY is applied to people and their actions. A DILATORY person delays, out of laziness, indifference, or simply out of a desire to delay. 
"Alan was so DILATORY in returning books that the library took away his card." 
"Realizing his company was short of cash, the accountant was DILATORY about paying bills." 
DILATORY actions are characterized by delay or are intended to delay. 
"The senator's DILATORY tactics prevented the bill from being considered before Congress adjourned."

EPIGONE.deftext:
an imitator, follower 
EPIGONE comes from the Greek _epigonoi_, which literally means "born after." In Greek legend, the Epigonoi were the sons of the seven leaders who had been defeated at Thebes; they, like their fathers, attacked that city. An EPIGONE is an imitator, usually a second-rate one. 
"The miserable EPIGONE spent his days copying Caravaggio's great works and dreaming of the day that he'd be famous." 
"The professor considers himself a follower of Plato's, but he is merely an EPIGONE: where Plato was profound the professor is merely pompous."

FEBRILE.deftext:
feverish 
FEBRILE is a close synonym of _feverish_. Both come from the Latin word for _fever_. FEBRILE comes to us through the French, _feverish_ through Old English. As is usually the case, the word that has been in the language longer is more commonly used and understood. 
"The child was hot and FEBRILE after the long, exhausting day." 
"The candidate's last FEBRILE burst of activity was not enough to stave off defeat." 
_Delicate_ is a common choice on the Pretest, perhaps due to a vague similarity of FEBRILE to _fragile_. _Diseased_ is also a common choice; it is probably chosen by people who have a vague idea of FEBRILE's meaning.

FRIABLE.deftext:
crumbly, brittle 
FRIABLE means "easily reduced to powder." The word is usually used about certain rocks or other materials that are brittle and crumble readily. 
"The FRIABLE piece of sandstone crumbled into a thousand pieces when I dropped it on the sidewalk." 
"The spade cut easily through the FRIABLE soil." 
"The FRIABLE chalk disintegrated as soon as the teacher tried to write with it."

LACUNA.deftext:
a gap, hole, empty space 
A LACUNA is a missing part, a gap. The word is often used about gaps of knowledge or gaps in a manuscript or inscription. The plural of LACUNA is LACUNAE or LACUNAS. 
"The professor is widely read, but she obviously has a LACUNA in the area of the physical sciences." 
"Several LACUNAE in the tattered old letter made its subject difficult to decipher." 
"There are many LACUNAS in our knowledge of how and when Shakespeare wrote his plays."

BENIGHTED.deftext:
ignorant, unenlightened 
The literal meaning of BENIGHTED is "covered over by night." In this sense the word might be used about travelers caught by darkness. Usually, however, the word is used figuratively, about people enveloped by the darkness of intellectual or moral ignorance. 
"The poor BENIGHTED peasants had never heard of these wonderful modern inventions." 
"The missionary wished to proclaim his beliefs to the BENIGHTED savages." 
"In those BENIGHTED times any woman who didn't marry was suspected of being a witch."

MORIBUND.deftext:
dormant, dying, obsolescent 
The Latin root _mor_ or _mort_ means _death_, and is found in such words as _mortal_, _mortuary_, and MORIBUND. The basic meaning of MORIBUND is "about to die." The word is more often used in a figurative sense about anything that is approaching an end. It is also used about things that are now lying dormant, but could come back to life in the future. 
"When funds ran out, the project became MORIBUND." 
"The oil shortage put new life into the MORIBUND coal industry, as people searched for alternative forms of energy." 
_Grotesque_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, possibly because MORIBUND is confused with _morbid_.

GELID.deftext:
icy, very cold 
GELID comes from the Latin word for _cold_, and is a synonym for _freezing_, _icy_. It tends to emphasize the discomfort of such cold. 
"The snowstorm brought such GELID weather that frostbite was epidemic." 
"Bob knew that he couldn't survive long in the GELID water: already his feet and hands were numb." 
The word is also used in a figurative sense. 
"The teacher's GELID stare indicated he had not found the student's remark amusing." 
_Weak_ is a common answer on the Pretest, perhaps because GELID looks and sounds like _jellied_.

DOYEN.deftext:
the senior member 
DOYEN is from the French and means "the senior member of a group." The word generally suggests experience and wisdom as a result of this position. The feminine of DOYEN is DOYENNE. 
"Because of his age and experience, the other members of the team regarded the designated hitter as the DOYEN of the team." 
"The 98-year-old man was unquestionably the DOYEN of the senior citizens' club; no one else was over 80."

NUGATORY.deftext:
worthless, trifling, futile, ineffectual 
Something that is NUGATORY is without value or significance. 
"Endless and mindless repetition of endearments can make them NUGATORY after a while." 
In a slightly different sense, NUGATORY can also describe something that has no effect, that doesn't work. In this sense NUGATORY is often applied to laws. 
"He had a deluded sense of self-importance, but his actual influence in politics was quite NUGATORY. After he left office few people remembered him." 
"All too often the laws that ban littering are NUGATORY in practice because they aren't enforced."

RECALCITRANT.deftext:
rebellious, refractory, defiant 
A RECALCITRANT person is actively defiant of another's authority. The word is stronger than _intractable_ or _refractory_, and suggests that it will be almost impossible to get the person to obey. 
"The RECALCITRANT sailor refused to obey the captain, and incited the rest of the crew to defy him as well." 
"In a dictatorship, even a small group of RECALCITRANT subjects is a threat." 
RECALCITRANT is occasionally used about things that are very difficult to control or treat. 
"He simply could not get the RECALCITRANT stereo system to work properly." "The doctor told us that the patients in the ward had a RECALCITRANT form of the disease." 
_Repentant_ and _reluctant_ are both commonly chosen wrong answers, perhaps because they look like RECALCITRANT. 
Other forms of the word: RECALCITRANCE, n. RECALCITRANCY, n.

SACERDOTAL.deftext:
priestly 
SACERDOTAL comes from the Latin word for _priest_; it is related to such English words as _sacred_ and _sacrament_. SACERDOTAL means "having to do with priests or the priesthood," _priestly_. 
"After every religious service, the SACERDOTAL garments were hung in a special closet." 
"The priest regretted that business matters intruded on his SACERDOTAL duties."

SATURNINE.deftext:
gloomy, dour, morose 
SATURNINE was originally a term in astrology, meaning "born under, or affected by the influence of, the planet Saturn." Such a person is supposed to have a gloomy, cold, sluggish temperament. The word has come into general use to describe any person with these characteristics. 
"Emily's SATURNINE disposition makes it difficult for anyone to know or like her." 
"One look at his SATURNINE countenance told us he was in no mood for joking." 
"The SATURNINE man sat silently in his room and brooded about the unhappiness of his life."

questions.prompt: Is a one-year jail sentence a CONDIGN punishment for littering?
Is it easy to ignore a CYNOSURE?
Is a cassock a HIERATIC garment?
Was the Civil War an INTERNECINE struggle?
Is Jimmy Carter a QUONDAM president?
Would a RECHERCHÉ activity be commonplace?
In ARCANE days people used to read books instead of watching television.
The treaty was temporarily ABROGATED until a couple of provisos could be changed.
Ralph could ADDUCE no examples of the man's immorality.
The thrilling conclusion to the symphony is ADUMBRATED by the initial simple presentation of the theme.
Mary's parents felt her punishment was CONDIGN, even though she complained that it was excessive.
Samantha wants to be the CYNOSURE of every party she attends.
The HIERATIC form of writing is indecipherable by lay people.
These INCHOATE longings for a different way of life eventually led her to change jobs.
The goal is INELUCTABLE; we will never make it.
An INTERNECINE commission was set up to study the causes of war.
The QUONDAM actress now spends her time writing and directing.
The meal consisted of oxtail soup, buffalo steaks, and other RECHERCHÉ foodstuffs.
The scholar's massive REDACTION of English folk ballads was incomplete at the time of his death.
He noticed the RETICULATE pattern of the city streets on the map.
The patient's STERTOROUS breathing alerted the doctors that something was the matter.

ARCANE.deftext:
mysterious, esoteric 
ARCANE comes from the Latin word for _chest_; it came to mean _secret_, _hidden_, like something hidden away in a chest. In English today it refers to something known only to a few people, and means _mysterious_. 
"The wizard said a few words in an ARCANE language and his wand turned into a snake." 
"We felt that there were ARCANE forces in the cave that were beyond our understanding." 
"He spent a lifetime seeking the ARCANE knowledge of the sages of the East." 
On the Pretest, people choose _ancient_, a wrong answer, more often than _mysterious_, the right one. This choice may be influenced by the word _archaic_. Something may be ARCANE because it is ancient, but the emphasis in ARCANE is on secret knowledge, not great age.

ABROGATE.deftext:
to repeal, annul, nullify 
To ABROGATE is to set aside or do away with. The word is most often used with regard to the actions of a ruler or a court in abolishing a law, treaty, or the like. 
"The new prime minister's first act was to ABROGATE all treaties with neighboring nations." 
"The lawyer claimed the Supreme Court's recent decisions were, in effect, ABROGATING the Bill of Rights." 
ABROGATE is also used in a more general way. 
"Janet refused to ABROGATE her principles for a temporary benefit." 
_Suspend_ is a more common choice on the Pretest than the correct answer, _repeal). ABROGATE is stronger than _suspend_; to ABROGATE something is to do away with it completely, not merely to stop it temporarily. 
Other forms of the word: ABROGATION, n.

ADDUCE.deftext:
to cite, bring forward for consideration 
See _ad-_ under Prefixes. The _duc_ root in ADDUCE comes from a Latin word meaning to _lead_; it is also found in such words as _induce_, _deduce_, and _reduce_. To ADDUCE something is to lead it to someone, to offer it or bring it forward. The word is used about facts, examples, or the like brought forward as evidence in a discussion. 
"The student ADDUCED several reasons in his paper for the decline of the Roman Empire." 
"She ADDUCED many examples as proof of the doctor's incompetence." 
"Since no facts were ADDUCED in support of his argument I must conclude that none exist." 
_Solve_ is chosen more frequently than the correct answer, _cite_, on the Pretest, probably due to the similarity of ADDUCE and _deduce_.

ADUMBRATE.deftext:
to foreshadow, suggest, prefigure, outline broadly 
The _umbra_ part of ADUMBRATE means _shadow_ in Latin; this root is also found in the word _umbrella_. See _ad-_ under Prefixes and _-ate1_ under Suffixes. To ADUMBRATE means to _foreshadow_, especially in a vague or sketchy way. 
"These happy times ADUMBRATE the joy we will someday feel when we live here permanently." 
In an extended sense, ADUMBRATE also means to _outline broadly_ or to _disclose partially_. 
"His brief synopsis could only ADUMBRATE the complexities of the novel." 
"The project was ADUMBRATED at a meeting last week; the complete proposal runs some two hundred pages." 
Other forms of the word: ADUMBRATION, n.

CONDIGN.deftext:
well-deserved, due, merited 
The _dign_ root in CONDIGN comes from a Latin word meaning _worthy_ or _deserving_; it is also found in the word _dignity_. CONDIGN at one time was applied to people and meant _deserving_. Now its use is limited to punishment and it means _well-deserved_, _fitting_. 
"The public felt that hanging was a CONDIGN punishment for the traitors." 
"The principal tried to decide what would be a CONDIGN punishment for Jimmy's offense."

CYNOSURE.deftext:
an attraction, center of attention 
CYNOSURE comes from Greek words meaning "dog's tail." The reference is one to the names for the constellation Ursa Minor, or the Little Dipper. One of the stars in Ursa Minor is Polaris, which is useful in navigation because it is situated close to the north pole in the heavens. Originally a CYNOSURE was something that served as a guide. Now it is used about anything that attracts, a focal point of attention or interest. 
"The brilliant young actress was the CYNOSURE of the film's opening night." 
"The newly renovated museum became a CYNOSURE for visitors to the city." 
_Flaw_ is chosen more frequently than the correct answer on the Pretest, _attraction_. This choice may be made by people who connect the _cyn_ in CYNOSURE with _cynicism_, a tendency to seek for flaws.

HIERATIC.deftext:
priestly, sacerdotal 
HIERATIC comes from a Greek word meaning _sacred_, the source of the word _hierarchy_, which originally referred specifically to religious officials organized into ranks or grades. The Greek word is also the source of the word _hieroglyphics_, the ancient Egyptian form of writing used by the priestly class. HIERATIC refers to a simplified form of hieroglyphics also used by priests. In general use it means "of or associated with priests or priestly duties." 
"With a solemn, HIERATIC gesture he bade us depart from the temple." 
"The HIERATIC vestments were folded and carefully put away for next year's ceremony." 
"His HIERATIC duties leave him no time for personal enjoyment."

INCHOATE.deftext:
incipient, just beginning, incomplete 
Note the pronunciation. 
INCHOATE means "in an early stage of existence; begun, but not fully formed." 
"The theory was not worked out fully until several years later. At this point it was half-formed, INCHOATE." 
"The INCHOATE affection they felt for each other never had a chance to ripen into true love." 
"You should tell them your ideas while the project is still INCHOATE and before it's too late to change anything." 
_Mixed_ is a common choice as the meaning of INCHOATE. INCHOATE usually contains the suggestion that, because something is in an early stage, it is disorganized and confused, and this may lead to the choice of _mixed_.

INELUCTABLE.deftext:
inevitable, inescapable 
The _eluct_ root in INELUCTABLE comes from a Latin word meaning to _struggle out_. The basic meaning of INELUCTABLE is "not able to be struggled out of." See _in-2_ under Prefixes and _-able_ under Suffixes. INELUCTABLE is a close synonym of _inevitable_, although it usually also contains the implication that struggling is useless. 
"He felt it was his INELUCTABLE destiny to be a loser." 
"Down by forty points in the last quarter, the coach watched the INELUCTABLE approach of defeat with quiet dignity." 
"The conclusion is INELUCTABLE: it was our fault and we will have to pay the damages." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _unreachable_, which is virtually an opposite of INELUCTABLE.

INTERNECINE.deftext:
deadly, destructive, characterized by internal struggle 
The basic meaning of INTERNECINE is "characterized by great bloodshed." It is often applied to battles that are mutually destructive, that cause carnage on both sides. 
"The encounter between the two hostile tribes led to an INTERNECINE slaughter." 
A more recent meaning of INTERNECINE, probably influenced by the word _internal_, is "involving struggle within a group." This newer meaning contains less of a sense of destruction or bloodshed. 
"The long INTERNECINE struggle within the party will surely hurt its chances in the general election."

QUONDAM.deftext:
former, onetime 
QUONDAM comes directly from Latin and means "having been at one time," _former_. It is a somewhat literary word, and would not generally be used in everyday conversation. 
"Pat discovered that her QUONDAM boyfriend was now saying nasty things about her." 
"This QUONDAM pacifist has now become an ardent supporter of the war." 
"The QUONDAM cigarette smoker has taken up chewing gum instead."

RECHERCHÉ.deftext:
exquisite, rare, exotic, precious 
Note the pronunciation. RECHERCHÉ is from the French, and retains its French pronunciation. 
RECHERCHÉ is related to the English word _research_. Its literal meaning in French is "sought after." It is usually used in English about something that is sought after because it is rare and, often, elegant. 
"The jaded aristocrats were forever seeking new and RECHERCHÉ ways to spend their money." 
"She dresses in a RECHERCHÉ style that is unusual but the height of good taste." 
RECHERCHÉ often has a negative connotation, suggesting overelegance or an inappropriate straining for a novel effect. 
"His stories are too RECHERCHÉ for the average reader. They are filled with archaic words, obscure literary allusions, and deliberately inscrutable characters." 
_Out-of-date_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, due to confusion with the word _passé_.

REDACTION.deftext:
revision, editing, adaptation 
REDACTION is the act of preparing something for publication. The word is generally not used about modern, everyday editorial work, but is a literary term used with reference to works of the past. It can imply either simple editing or a more elaborate revision or adaptation by someone other than the original author. 
"There were probably many versions of the _Iliad_ and the _Odyssey_ before they underwent a REDACTION that produced the poems we know today." 
"The REDACTION of this material must have presented many difficult decisions to the medieval monks." 
A REDACTION is also the work produced as a result of the editing. 
"The eighteenth-century REDACTIONS of Shakespeare's play were infinitely inferior to the originals." 
Other forms of the word: REDACT, v. REDACTOR, n.

RETICULATE.deftext:
net-like, forming a network 
RETICULATE and the similar adjectives _reticulated_ and _reticular_ all come from a Latin word meaning "a little net," and all mean "forming or resembling a network." 
"Through the microscope you could see the RETICULATE pattern of fibers in the paper." 
"The RETICULATE wing was crisscrossed with tiny veins."

STERTOROUS.deftext:
snoring, characterized by snoring 
STERTOR is a medical term for a heavy snoring sound made while breathing. STERTOROUS is the adjective from STERTOR. See _-ous_ under Suffixes. STERTOROUS means "characterized by a loud snoring sound." It is often used about breathing. 
"No one could sleep listening to the STERTOROUS breathing of the asthmatic man." 
"Jane finds the STERTOROUS sounds of her sleeping husband oddly reassuring." 
Other forms of the word: STERTOR, n.

questions.prompt: Should a scientific article be TENDENTIOUS?
Could a diminutive person have a STENTORIAN voice?
Is humor a SALIENT feature of a Marx Brothers movie?
Could a criminal AVER that he is innocent?
Can you DESCRY something with a microscope?
Would a person be likely to receive an ENCOMIUM for deplorable behavior?
Would a BALEFUL look betray a dislike for someone?
Is it shameful to TRADUCE someone?
They accused the government of SUBORNING the witness with the promise of a job if he cooperated.
We thought the travel agent was being TENDENTIOUS in describing nothing but the good points of the island.
Through the foggy, TENEBROUS London night Holmes and Watson pursued the criminal.
The workers covered their ears when the boss issued his STENTORIAN commands.
Jim's most SALIENT trait is an inability to accept criticism.
The boss thought the workers' attitude was OPPROBRIOUS: they didn't care about doing a good job.
The defendant AVERRED being with the deceased on the night of the murder.
His story LANGUISHED for months on the editor's desk before it was finally read.
Despite the camouflage we managed to DESCRY the enemy's tanks.
The juvenile delinquent paid no attention to the judge's stern ENCOMIUMS.
Their BALEFUL marriage finally ended in divorce.
The flag hung LIMPID in the dead air.
The con man TRADUCED the woman into giving him her life savings.
The preacher condemned the movie as VENIAL and depraved.
The PRODIGAL explorer never spent more than six months in the same place.

SUBORN.deftext:
to bribe, instigate, induce to commit 
To SUBORN a person is to induce him or her, by secret or illegal means, to commit a crime. SUBORN is particularly used with reference to perjury. 
"The mobster SUBORNED the witness to change his testimony by buying him a new car." 
"The spy SUBORNED the clerk to remove the secret documents from the file." 
"Three of the jurors were SUBORNED by the unscrupulous defense attorney and agreed to vote 'Not Guilty' for a fee." 
_Replace_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest, possibly because of a vague resemblance between SUBORN and _substitute_. 
Other forms of the word: SUBORNATION, n.

TENDENTIOUS.deftext:
biased, not impartial 
TENDENTIOUS is an adjective from the noun _tendency_. A person or thing that is TENDENTIOUS has a tendency to support a particular cause or point of view, is not objective. 
"She wrote a TENDENTIOUS article praising the mayor's record and ridiculing his opponent." 
"I thought the politician was rather TENDENTIOUS in his speech—mentioning all the good things about his party and ignoring its weaknesses." 
"Advertisements on TV are at best TENDENTIOUS, at worst deliberately misleading." 
_Pompous_ and _misleading_ are the common mistakes. _Pompous_ is probably chosen due to confusion with _pretentious_. Something that it TENDENTIOUS may also be misleading, because the truth is not as important as promoting a point of view. The emphasis, however, is on this lack of impartiality.

TENEBROUS.deftext:
gloomy, dark, murky 
TENEBROUS is a somewhat literary term meaning "dark and gloomy." It can be used about actual physical darkness: 
"There were living creatures even in the TENEBROUS depths of the cave." 
Or it can be used in a figurative sense: 
"The TENEBROUS atmosphere created by the Gothic novel was both mysterious and frightening." 
_Flimsy_ and _stubborn_ are the most commonly chosen wrong answers. _Flimsy_ is probably chosen because TENEBROUS looks vaguely like _tenuous_; _stubborn_ because it looks like _tenacious_.

STENTORIAN.deftext:
loud, earsplitting, resounding 
STENTOR was a Greek warrior in the _Iliad_ famous for his loud, powerful voice. STENTORIAN is the adjective from STENTOR. It is usually applied to voices and means _extremely loud_. 
"In a STENTORIAN voice the sergeant shouted out his orders to the troops." 
"The orator's STENTORIAN tones could be heard in every part of the huge hall." 
"Cindy didn't know how to whisper; when she tried to speak softly her voice was still STENTORIAN."

SALIENT.deftext:
prominent, striking, conspicuous 
SALIENT comes from a Latin word meaning to _leap_. SALIENTIA is the scientific name for the group of animals that includes frogs and toads. In English SALIENT sometimes has the basic meaning of _leaping_ or _jumping_, particularly with reference to animals. Commonly, however, the word is used in a figurative sense of things that "leap out" at you, that are prominent and significant. 
"The most SALIENT characteristic of the company's salespeople is their aggressiveness." 
"The one SALIENT fact is that someone is dead; nothing else is important." 
"The critic said that the SALIENT feature of television news is its superficiality." 
_Crucial_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer. SALIENT usually implies that there is some importance and significance to the thing it describes, but the emphasis is on its prominence. 
Other forms of the word: SALIENCE, n.

OPPROBRIOUS.deftext:
shameful, disgraceful, scurrilous, abusive 
OPPROBRIUM is disgrace that results from shameful conduct. 
"The public OPPROBRIUM was so great following the scandal that the president was forced to resign in disgrace." 
OPPROBRIOUS is the adjective from OPPROBRIUM. When used about language, it means "expressing OPPROBRIUM." 
"She made OPPROBRIOUS comments about businessmen who don't care about the safety of their products." 
In general, OPPROBRIOUS means "deserving OPPROBRIUM," _shameful_, _infamous_. 
"Your OPPROBRIOUS conduct must be condemned by every right-thinking person." 
Other forms of the word: OPPROBRIUM, n.

AVER.deftext:
to assert, affirm, declare 
The _ver_ part of AVER comes from a Latin word meaning _true_; it is also found in such words as _verify_ and _verdict_. To AVER something is to declare confidently that it is true. 
"The governor AVERRED that nothing could make him raise taxes." 
"The coach AVERRED that his team would win the championship easily." 
"Several witnesses heard him AVER that he would get even if it was the last thing he did." 
On the Pretest, _deny_, an exact opposite, is chosen more frequently than the correct answer, _assert_. People who choose _deny_ are familiar with AVER, but perhaps haven't seen it often enough to remember whether to AVER something is to say it is true or say it is false.

LANGUISH.deftext:
to grow weak, droop, fade, pine 
LANGUISH, _languor_, and _languid_ all come from a Latin word meaning to _feel faint_. The basic meaning of LANGUISH is to grow weak, to lose strength. 
"Without water the plants quickly began to LANGUISH." 
LANGUISH also means "to continue in a state of suffering or neglect." 
"He LANGUISHED in prison for ten years before finally being released." 
Particularly in its participial form, LANGUISHING, the word is used about an affected attitude of weariness or wistfulness. 
"With a LANGUISHING sigh she said that if only she could get to Moscow, everything would be all right."

DESCRY.deftext:
to notice, discern, espy 
To DESCRY means to _catch sight of_. The word implies keen vision that allows one to see something despite great distance or other hindrance. 
"The townspeople could just barely DESCRY the masts of the ships on the horizon." 
"The lookout DESCRIED the Indians moving stealthily through the trees." 
DESCRY can also be used in a figurative sense about anything that is discovered by keen mental observation. 
"She thought she DESCRIED a pattern in the murderer's behavior." 
_Fear_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer, perhaps because of the _cry_ part of DESCRY.

ENCOMIUM.deftext:
a eulogy, tribute, panegyric 
An ENCOMIUM is a formal, usually public, expression of praise. The plural of ENCOMIUM is either ENCOMIA or ENCOMIUMS. 
"The president's ENCOMIUM of basic American values stirred the hearts of his listeners." 
"Despite all these ENCOMIA the returning hero remained humble." 
"Moved by the ENCOMIUM to Martin Luther King, Jr., Jack resolved to learn more about the man." 
_Reward_ is the most commonly chosen wrong answer. An ENCOMIUM can be thought of as a kind of reward, but it is specifically an expression of praise.

BALEFUL.deftext:
ominous, sinister, malign, dire 
BALE is a poetic or archaic word meaning _harm_ or _disaster_. Something that it BALEFUL threatens evil or disaster, often because it is evil itself. 
"The teacher's BALEFUL look convinced John that he should start behaving." 
"The economists' BALEFUL predictions of a worldwide depression never came true." 
"Mary's parents feared the BALEFUL influence the drifter had over her." 
_Unhappy_ is by far the most common choice on the Pretest. Something that is BALEFUL can cause unhappiness, but it is not necessarily unhappy.

LIMPID.deftext:
clear, transparent, translucent 
LIMPID means "having the transparent clearness of water." It is often used in an extended sense about writing that is clear and readily intelligible. It sometimes also suggests calmness and serenity. 
"The LIMPID water of the lake allowed us to see all the way to the bottom." 
"The LIMPID grace of his essays is unmatched in English prose." 
"No one could fail to be impressed by the nun's LIMPID, serene holiness." 
Most people choose _soft_ as the meaning of LIMPID, obviously misled by the _limp_ part of the word. 
Other forms of the word: LIMPIDITY, n.

TRADUCE.deftext:
to slander, defame, malign, libel 
The common root _duce_, found in such words as _reduce_, _produce_, and _induce_, means to _lead_. See _tra-_ under Prefixes. TRADUCE originally was used as a synonym of transport. It then came to mean "leading across as a spectacle," and finally reached its current meaning, "to speak evil of," to _slander_. 
"The book TRADUCES a great man with its unsupported accusations and sly innuendoes." 
"The politician was not above planting false stories in the newspaper that TRADUCED his rivals." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _deceive_, probably because of confusion with _seduce_. To TRADUCE a person is not to deceive him, but to speak evil of him. This might deceive others, but it would not deceive the person being TRADUCED. 
Other forms of the word: TRADUCEMENT, n.

VENIAL.deftext:
excusable, insignificant, pardonable, forgivable 
VENIAL comes from a Latin word for _forgiveness_ and is related to Venus, the Roman goddess of love. VENIAL is used about faults or sins that are not serious enough to require punishment, that are easily pardonable. In Roman Catholic theology, VENIAL sins are contrasted with mortal sins. A VENIAL sin is a minor offense against divine law, while a mortal sin is a serious offense that merits eternal punishment. 
"These VENIAL faults are not worth punishing; just explain to him what he did wrong." 
"Sheila thought her offense was VENIAL, but the dean felt it merited expulsion." 
The most commonly chosen wrong answer is _immoral_, a word that might be used in the same situation as VENIAL. A VENIAL sin or offense might be immoral, but mainly it is excusable, insignificant.

PRODIGAL.deftext:
extravagant, wasteful; lavish, profuse 
PRODIGAL means "given to extravagance." The word generally suggests waste and recklessness. 
"Unless you check your PRODIGAL habits of spending you will soon be ruined." 
It does not always have a totally negative connotation, however, and may mean _lavish_, _profuse_. 
"The kind theater critic was PRODIGAL in his praise of the young performers." 
"That spring the PRODIGAL earth brought forth flowers in incredible abundance." 
Three times as many people pick _wandering_ as pick the correct answer, _extravagant_, on the Pretest. These people have been misled by the parable of the prodigal son. The PRODIGAL son wanders far from home and wastes his money. PRODIGAL refers to the wasting, not the wandering. 
Other forms of the word: PRODIGALITY, n.

questions.prompt: Does a rebellious person have an EQUABLE temperament?
Is the Declaration of Independence APOCRYPHAL?
Do most people find IMPRECATIONS shameful?
Would extravagant spending VITIATE an attempt to economize?
Does a PERSPICUOUS writing style tend to be overly wordy?
Do sterilized needles OBVIATE the danger of infection?
Could too much flattery be FULSOME?
Would SCURRILOUS language be acceptable in a classroom?
Would you IMPUGN someone's work by calling it worthless?
Could excessive praise be considered EXIGUOUS?
One of the heirs complained that the division of the inheritance wasn't EQUABLE.
The book was full of APOCRYPHAL tales that sounded true but had no reliable source.
The man's REFULGENT belly made him look a bit like Santa Claus.
The principal gave Jane an award for MERETRICIOUS conduct.
The rowdy people shouted IMPRECATIONS at the police as they departed.
The poor officiating VITIATED what should have been an exciting game.
The teenager lifts weights and works out so that he will be PROTEAN.
She is an excellent debater; her arguments are always PERSPICUOUS and to the point.
A trained counselor can OBVIATE some of the problems associated with release from prison.
The employer's FULSOME letter of recommendation made the worker sound like a candidate for sainthood.
The comedian's SCURRILOUS jokes did not appeal to the more refined members of the audience.
Feeling his honor had been IMPUGNED, the officer challenged the man to a duel.
We do not deserve such OBLOQUY; we have done nothing to be ashamed of.
It is my EXIGUOUS duty to inform you of your arrest.
The minister began to feel his sermons were OTIOSE; the people in his congregation would never change.

EQUABLE.deftext:
even-tempered, steady, unvarying 
EQUABLE comes from the Latin word for _equal_. EQUABLE's general meaning is _steady_, _uniform_. 
"He wants an EQUABLE climate where he won't have to worry about extremes in temperature." 
It is most often applied to a person's temperament or an expression of it; in this sense it means _even-tempered_, _tranquil_. 
"We need someone with an EQUABLE disposition—someone who won't fly off the handle if something goes wrong." 
"The teacher's EQUABLE manner in turn made her students relaxed and happy." 
Fair-minded is a more common choice in the Pretest than the correct answer, _even-tempered_, due to confusion between EQUABLE and _equitable_.

APOCRYPHAL.deftext:
spurious, counterfeit, of doubtful authenticity 
The APOCRYPHA are early Christian writings of doubtful authenticity or authorship. The word has also come to be used about any writings of questionable authenticity. APOCRYPHAL is the adjective from APOCRYPHA. Although the emphasis of the word is on the trustworthiness of the source of something, it also often suggests that the thing itself is untrue. 
"This story is probably APOCRYPHAL, although it has been attributed to Mark Twain." 
"These APOCRYPHAL poems were once thought to have been written by Homer." 
"He told an anecdote, possibly APOCRYPHAL, about George Washington's kindness to his mother." 
_Mysterious_ is a more common choice than the correct synonym, _spurious_, perhaps because of the mysterious nature of the origins of the APOCRYPHA, and perhaps because of a confusion with the Apocalypse, the book of the Bible which describes the future in mysterious symbols. 
Other forms of the word: APOCRYPHA, n.

REFULGENT.deftext:
gleaming, radiant, brilliant 
The _fulg_ part of REFULGENT comes from a Latin word meaning to _shine_. This root is also found in the English word _effulgent_, which has much the same meaning as REFULGENT. REFULGENT means "shining brightly, brilliantly resplendent." 
"Her REFULGENT jewels glittered in the candlelight." 
"The REFULGENT new cars gleamed as the salesman led us through the lot." 
_Swelling_ is by far the most commonly chosen wrong answer, probably due to the similarity of the _fulge_ sound to the word _bulge_. 
Other forms of the word: REFULGENCE, n. REFULGENCY, n.

MERETRICIOUS.deftext:
tawdry, gaudy; insincere, spurious 
MERETRICIOUS comes from the Latin word for _prostitute_, which in turn comes from a word meaning to _earn_, also the source of the word _merit_. The basic meaning of MERETRICIOUS is "like a prostitute." In an extended sense, MERETRICIOUS refers to anything that is attractive in a cheap or deceitful way or that is based on insincerity. 
"The critic decried the MERETRICIOUS appeal of the situation comedy, which was based on slapstick and vulgarity rather than on sophisticated humor." 
"Her beauty was MERETRICIOUS, a product of heavy makeup and flattering camera angles." 
"His arguments are MERETRICIOUS; they are superficially plausible, but in fact they are cynical attempts to manipulate our emotions." 
_Exemplary_ is twice as popular as the correct answer, _tawdry_, on the Pretest, probably due to the influence of the words _merit_ and _meritorious_.

IMPRECATION.deftext:
cursing; a curse 
To IMPRECATE is to call down curses upon. IMPRECATION is the act of cursing or the curse itself. 
"IMPRECATION is not a socially acceptable method of displaying anger." 
"Muttering IMPRECATIONS under his breath, the driver sat and fumed in the heavy traffic." 
More people choose _accusation_ on the Pretest than the correct answer, _cursing_. This may be due to the similarity of the words IMPRECATION and _implication_, or _accusation_ may be chosen because both accusations and cursing may be the result of anger. 
Other forms of the word: IMPRECATE, v.

VITIATE.deftext:
to spoil, contaminate, corrupt, debase, pervert 
Both VITIATE and the more common word _vice_ come ultimately from a Latin word meaning _defeat_ or _fault_. To VITIATE something is to make it defective, faulty, or impure. The word is used about physical objects like the air and, more frequently, about abstractions like morality. 
"His insane jealousy VITIATED their otherwise loving relationship." 
"The novel is VITIATED by the author's obvious hatred of male characters." 
"Their effectiveness as a team was VITIATED by their mutual dislike." 
_Cleanse_ is more than twice as popular as the correct answer on the Pretest, _spoil_. This may be due to words like _obviate_ and _alleviate_, which sound like VITIATE, but have almost the opposite meaning. 
Other forms of the word: VITIATION, n.

PROTEAN.deftext:
changeable, variable, versatile 
In Greek mythology, PROTEUS was a sea god who could assume different shapes at will. PROTEAN is the adjective from PROTEUS. It is used about both physical objects and abstract qualities that can readily take on different shapes or appearances. 
"The artist loved the sea's PROTEAN quality: it was never the same color or shape twice." 
"Her PROTEAN disposition makes her difficult to live with: you never know when she will be happy or sad or angry." 
"The PROTEAN actor is capable of transforming himself instantly into any of a hundred different characters." 
Most people pick _powerful_ as the meaning of PROTEAN. Perhaps they are thinking of _herculean_, another adjective derived from Greek mythology. Or perhaps there is some confusion with the noun _protein_.

PERSPICUOUS.deftext:
clear, lucid 
PERSPICUOUS is used about style or mode of expression and means "easy to understand," _clear_. Like the similar word _conspicuous_, it comes originally from a Latin word meaning to _see_. 
"His essays are noted for a PERSPICUOUS style that makes them easy to read and understand." 
"The speaker was not at all PERSPICUOUS in his remarks; at times it seemed as if he was purposely trying to confuse us." 
_Hidden_ is the most commonly chosen answer on the Pretest; perhaps people who are unfamiliar with PERSPICUOUS guess that it is an opposite of _conspicuous_. 
Other forms of the word: PERSPICUITY, n.

OBVIATE.deftext:
to prevent, make unnecessary 
To OBVIATE something is to anticipate it and make it unnecessary, for example by removing the conditions under which it may occur. 
"Good nutrition now will OBVIATE the need for expensive medical treatments later on." 
"Putting your valuables in the hotel safe OBVIATES the risk of theft." 
"Careful planning and attention to detail will OBVIATE the confusion generally associated with large conventions." 
OBVIATE comes from the same Latin root as _obvious_. The similarity of the words probably explains why _reveal_ is the most popular choice on the Pretest. Despite the similar derivations, however, OBVIATE has a very different meaning from _obvious_.

FULSOME.deftext:
sickening, repulsive, disgustingly excessive 
FULSOME comes from the word _full_ and the suffix _-some_, which means "tending to be." 
FULSOME originally meant _abundant_, but in modern usage it has come to mean _grossly excessive_ and is used about something like praise that can be overdone to the point of being sickening. 
"The young queen quickly tired of the FULSOME compliments of the courtiers." 
"The critic's FULSOME praise of the trashy movie suggested that he had been bought off by its press agents." 
"The introduction to the book was admiring but not FULSOME; it said the book was not without flaws, but deserved our attention." 
FULSOME is often seen without this negative connotation, with a meaning close to its original sense of _abundant_. This probably accounts for the popularity of _pleasant_ as an answer on the Pretest. This use of FULSOME, however, is generally considered to be incorrect.

SCURRILOUS.deftext:
abusive, foul-mouthed, vituperative 
SCURRILOUS means "given to or containing coarse, abusive language." 
"Certain SCURRILOUS people scrawled obscenities all over the wall." 
"The mayor said he wouldn't dignify his opponent's SCURRILOUS charges with a reply." 
"The speaker attacked organized religion in such SCURRILOUS terms that we were deeply offended." 
More people choose _sneaky_ as the meaning of SCURRILOUS on the Pretest than choose the correct synonym, _abusive_, perhaps because of the unrelated verb to _scurry_. 
Other forms of the word: SCURRILITY, n.

IMPUGN.deftext:
to contradict, refute, call into question, malign 
The _pugn_ part of IMPUGN comes from a Latin word meaning _fight_; it is also found in the word _pugnacious_. IMPUGN has the pronunciation it does because it comes into English through French. IMPUGN originally meant to _attack physically_. Now it means "to attack with words," to criticize as false or call into question. 
"How dare you IMPUGN my honesty! I have never lied in my life." 
"She IMPUGNED his motives, saying he was helping her in hopes of a reward." 
"The boss IMPUGNED Bill's work on the project, calling it of questionable value." 
_Suspect_ is the most frequently marked wrong answer. IMPUGN goes one step further than _suspect_; one who IMPUGNS not only suspects but actively calls into question.

OBLOQUY.deftext:
abuse, vituperation, calumny; disgrace, dishonor, ignominy 
OBLOQUY comes from a Latin word meaning to _speak against_; the _loqu_ root is also found in _loquacious_. OBLOQUY has two related meanings. The first is "abusive and defamatory language," _calumny_. 
"The hostile newspapers subjected the mayor to continuous OBLOQUY." 
OBLOQUY is also the disgrace and ill repute of a person who has been subjected to this abusive language. 
"He was never able to live down the OBLOQUY of having been called a traitor." 
"After her release from prison the confessed child-murderer lived in OBLOQUY the rest of her days."

EXIGUOUS.deftext:
scanty, meager, skimpy 
EXIGUOUS means "small in amount or size," _scanty_. It comes from a Latin word meaning to _weigh_ or _measure_; the idea is of something that is measured and found lacking. 
"His EXIGUOUS income is barely enough to support one person, let alone two." 
"The prisoners were forced to live on an EXIGUOUS diet of bread and water." 
"Their rather EXIGUOUS ranks were depleted still further when three students decided to leave the team." 
Other forms of the word: EXIGUITY, n.

OTIOSE.deftext:
idle, indolent; ineffective, futile, useless 
OTIOSE has two related meanings. The first is _idle_, _at leisure_. 
"He condemned these OTIOSE young men who had never done a good day's work in their lives." 
From this OTIOSE has come to mean "lacking in effectiveness," _futile_ or _functionless_. 
"The announcer felt that words were OTIOSE at a moment of such high drama, so he said nothing." 
"The consultant said the whole department was OTIOSE and should be terminated." 
Other forms of the word: OTIOSITY, n.
